Cross reference— Personnel, Ch. 15. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Secs. 2-1—2-19. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - MEETINGS OF GOVERNING BODY 
 
Sec. 2-20. - Place, time and day of regular meetings. 
The regular monthly meeting of the governing body shall be held in the council chamber in the city hall, at the hour of 6:00 p.m. on the second Thursday of each month. 
(Code 1966, § 2-18; Ord. No. 3130, § 1, 12-13-82; Ord. No. 88-3422, § 1, 10-26-88)  
Sec. 2-21. - Order of business at regular meetings; agenda. 
(a)  Unless this section of these rules of procedure is suspended at any regular meeting by the unanimous vote of all members present, the following shall be the order of business at all regular meetings of the governing body; provided that the mayor will call and the governing body will consider items on the agenda in the order upon which persons who may be present in the council room are interested, prior to calling those items upon which no person interested is present: 
(1)  Call to order. 
(2)  Prayer. 
(3)  Reading of minutes of the preceding regular meeting and of special meetings held since the preceding regular meeting. 
(4)  Public hearings of citizens and of citizens' committees. 
(5)  Consideration of and action on reports of committees appointed of the governing body. 
(6)  Reports of city officials or employees required by law or by action of the governing body. 
(7)  Action on ordinances and resolutions introduced at previous meetings. 
(8)  Other unfinished business. 
(9)  Introduction of, and permitted action on proposed ordinances and resolutions. 
(10)  Other new business. 
(11)  Communications. 
(12)  Adjournment. 
(b)  Prior to each regular meeting, the city clerk shall prepare an agenda of all matters which such clerk knows may be considered at the meeting, arranged in the order set forth above in sufficient detail to explain the nature of the item. 
(Code 1966, § 2-19)  
Sec. 2-22. - Special meetings—Calling; notices; actions. 
(a)  The mayor or any member of the governing body may call a special meeting of the governing body to be held at the place and at the time set forth in the notice of the special meeting. All notices of the special meeting shall be issued by the city clerk and shall contain a statement of the specific items of business to be transacted, and shall be served by a police officer on the mayor and all members of the governing body who have not signed it and who can be found personally, at least eight (8) hours before the time fixed for the meeting. 
(b)  The notice with endorsement of its services shall be entered on the minutes of the special meeting. The mayor and any or all the members of the governing body may waive notice of the meeting in writing. 
(c)  No business except that specified in the call shall be transacted at the meeting except by unanimous consent of the governing body. In all cases a majority of the members elected shall be required to transact business. 
(Code 1966, §§ 2-07, 2-20)  
Sec. 2-23. - Same—Order of business. 
The following shall be the order of business at all special meetings of the governing body: 
(1)  Call to order. 
(2)  Roll call. 
(3)  Proof of notice of the meeting or waiver thereof by members not proven to have been notified properly. 
(4)  Consideration of the specific items of business stated in the call for such special meeting. 
(Code 1966, § 2-21)  
Sec. 2-24. - Quorum. 
Three (3) or more members of the governing body present at any regular or special meeting of the governing body shall constitute a quorum. 
(Code 1966, §§ 2-07, 2-22)  
Sec. 2-25. - Journal of proceedings. 
The city clerk shall keep a journal of the proceedings of the governing body at all regular and special meetings to be labelled "Municipal Minutes, City of Bastrop." 
(Code 1966, § 2-23)  
Sec. 2-26. - Conducting of meetings; public hearings. 
The mayor, or in the mayor's absence the mayor pro tempore, shall at all times have full charge and responsibility for the conduct of all meetings of the governing body. Any party desiring to be heard by the governing body shall be given time at any regular meeting to present such party's plea. By a majority vote of the governing body, time to any one (1) individual or any one (1) group of individuals may be limited to fifteen (15) minutes. 
(Code 1966, § 2-24)  
Sec. 2-27. - Procedural matters not covered. 
Any point or matter of procedure shall be determined according to the rules set forth in Robert's Rules of Order, Revised. 
(Code 1966, § 2-25)  
Secs. 2-28—2-40. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - BOARDS, COMMISSIONS, COMMITTEES  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Secs. 2-41—2-50. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - EMPLOYEE HEALTH BOARD[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Section 6 of Ord. No. 89-3444 repealed Ord. No. 88-3395, adopted June 14, 1988, from which form §§ 2-51—2-54 were derived. The editor has included §§ 1—3 of Ord. No. 89-3444 as a new Div. 2, §§ 2-51—2-54. 
Cross reference— Personnel, Ch. 15. 
 
Sec. 2-51. - Established; membership. 
There is hereby established an employee health board, an administrative board of the city. This employee health board shall consist of twelve (12) members with one (1) member from each of the following identified departments, three (3) elected representatives from the retired employees of the city and the mayor of the city. 
(1)  Executive and administrative departments. 
(2)  City court. 
(3)  Police department. 
(4)  Fire department. 
(5)  Street and cemetery departments. 
(6)  Sewer department and city garage. 
(7)  Recreation and purchasing. 
(8)  Board of aldermen of the city. 
(Ord. No. 89-3444, § 1, 8-8-89)  
Sec. 2-52. - Authority and powers. 
This board shall have the full authority and power to amend health insurance policies covering active and retired employees of the city and/or to change insurance companies, if desired, by the board, it being provided, however, that the amount of contributions by the city as an employer shall be in the sole discretion of the mayor and board of aldermen. 
(Ord. No. 89-3444, § 1, 8-8-89)  
Sec. 2-53. - Election of members; vacancies; chairperson. 
Members of the employee health board shall be elected every four (4) years, such election to be immediately after the installation of the mayor and board of aldermen of the city. Any vacancy on the board shall be filled by special election by members of the representative group where such vacancy exists. The duly elected mayor of the city shall be the chairperson of such board. 
(Ord. No. 89-3444, § 2, 8-8-89)  
Sec. 2-54. - Compensation; meetings; recordkeeping. 
Members of the employee health board shall serve without pay, and shall hold such meetings as shall be necessary to properly attend to the duties of the board. The board shall be called into meeting at the written request of the elected mayor of the city or upon the written request of at least three (3) members of the board. The employee health board shall keep such records as are necessary to the conduct of its business, shall keep minutes of all its meetings and shall keep a record of each decision made by such board. The duly elected mayor shall furnish office help to the employee health board to assist with recordkeeping. 
(Ord. No. 89-3444, § 3, 8-8-89)  
Secs. 2-55—2-70. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - TECHNOLOGY AND COMMUNICATION POLICY[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note— Ordinance No. 08-4160, adopted April 10, 2008, did not specifically amend the Code. Therefore, such ordinance has been added as § 2-71. 
 
Sec. 2-71. - Requirements and guidelines. 
The City of Bastrop Technology and Communication Policy provides you with requirements and guidance regarding using city e-mail, telephone, voicemail, fax, the internet and other city technology systems. 
The City of Bastrop e-mail, telephone, voicemail, fax, Internet and technology systems belong to the city, and the city reserves the right to monitor and examine all communications over these systems at its discretion. Accordingly, no employee should have any expectation of privacy as to his or her Internet or technology systems usage and should not use these systems for information they wish to keep private. These systems should be used primarily for city-related business. Personal use of e-mail, voicemail, fax and the Internet is acceptable, but should be done using good judgment and with the recognition that these systems are provided in order to conduct business. Federal and state law and city policies regarding misuse of city property, discrimination, harassment, sexual harassment, and confidential information apply to the use of all city technology systems. 
The city reserves the right to inspect any and all files stored in all areas of the City of Bastrop network, including those assigned to individual employees, and those stored on any city computer, in order to assure compliance with this and other city policies. 
Employees are not allowed to: 
a.  Violate copyright law by downloading, duplicating, installing or using unlicensed software or by transmitting copyrighted materials belonging to entities other than the city. Failure to observe copyright or license agreements may result in disciplinary action from the city or legal action by a copyright owner; 
b.  Hack or attempt to hack into other networks including: attempting to gain access to restricted resources inside or outside the City of Bastrop network; 
c.  Use the Internet in such a way that it disrupts the operation of the city network or the networks of other users; 
d.  Share personal files to the Internet; and 
e.  Use the Internet or technology systems to send messages with derogatory or inflammatory remarks about an individual or group's age, disability, gender, race, religion, national origin, physical attributes, sexual preference, political beliefs or any other classification protected by federal, state or local law. 
f.  Use of any proxy service or software that disguises or masks user identity or location. 
(Ord. No. 08-4160, 4-10-08) 
Prohibited uses of city owned digital equipment 
City equipment may not be used for any of the following purposes as defined by city policy, ethics rules and city and state laws (this is not necessarily an all inclusive list - others may apply and the user is charged with using discretion): 
Conducting private business, political campaigning, announcing union membership meetings or conducting other exclusively union business, making unauthorized general message distributions to all users ("everyone"), sharing or storing unlicensed software or audio/video files, distribution of any video or still images without prior city approval, or any other illegal usage. 
Waiver of privacy rights 
Employee expressly waives any right of privacy in anything they create, store, send, or receive using the city's computer equipment or Internet access. User consents to allow city IT personnel access to and review of all materials created, stored, sent, or received by employee through any city network or Internet connection. 
Software 
All software installed on computers provided by the city will be legally obtained and licensed. All software may only be installed by the IT department. Personal software installed on city computers is prohibited. Employees are prohibited from installing software on city computers in violation of license agreements. Doing so makes the city liable for damages relating to claims of copyright infringement and software piracy. Any employee found to be in violation of this policy will be subject to immediate termination. Software requests must be made to your supervisor if you have a work-related need for commercial software and can only be installed by the IT department. 
Copyrighted Material 
The city is committed to respecting intellectual property rights and does not condone or support its employees' use of certain web sites that could be considered a violation of copyright law. While the city will only restrict access to a service to control bandwidth utilization, we urge you to use your best judgment when using the city network to avoid copyright infringement and to respect the intellectual property rights of others. 
Email 
Email is provided as an essential tool in communicating both inside and outside the city for business-related purposes. The city reserves the right to periodically monitor email. Therefore, employees should not consider their conversations over city-provided email to be private. 
Instant Messenger 
If instant messenger accounts and or software are needed they will be provided by the city. Employees are not to install or use instant messengers unless approved by the city. The city reserves the right to periodically review instant mail chat logs. Therefore, employees should not consider their conversations over instant messenger sessions to be private. 
Passwords 
Employees are prohibited from giving out personal passwords to anyone internal or external of the city. Employee passwords will be provided by the Human Resources Department. 
Email and instant messenger etiquette 
Employees are expected to treat all employees and non-employees with the same courtesy and respect via email and instant messenger (IM) communications as they would in face-to-face discourse. 
Computer Usage 
Employees must take measures to protect sensitive customer and city information stored on their computers. 
Hardware 
Purchase and installation of new or upgraded equipment, including computer systems, cabling, keyboards, mice, printers, modems, plotters, monitors, software, memory, hard drives, etc., must be accomplished by way of the IT Department. Employees may not install ANY personal equipment or software. 
Internet Usage 
We realize that every employee at the city may have a legitimate need for full, unfiltered Internet access. Unfiltered Internet access is provided for the purposes of performing day-to-day business tasks. Employees must realize that they share an Internet connection and the transfer capacity of that connection is not infinite. If the City of Bastrop Internet connection becomes unusually slow, the city reserves the right to monitor Internet traffic to determine the cause of the problem and to identify troublesome users or applications. Excessive use of the Internet for activities not directly related to workplace tasks may result in disciplinary action, up to and including termination of employment. 
Blocking sites with inappropriate content 
The city has the right to utilize software that makes it possible to identify and block access to Internet sites containing sexually explicit or other material deemed inappropriate in the workplace. 
Telephone Usage 
The telephone system (including voicemail) at the city is the property of the city and is provided for business purposes. The city may periodically monitor the usage of the telephone systems to ensure compliance with this policy. Therefore, employees should not consider their conversations or recorded voicemail on the City of Bastrop telephone system to be private. 
Monitoring and Tracking 
The city may monitor or track employee with video, GPS, RFID or any tracking/monitoring system. Any negative information gathered by these devices or software may be used for disciplinary action or termination. 
Public Records and Records Retention 
In accordance with the Louisiana Public Records Law and the Federal Freedom of Information Act, all records, which includes all writings, recordings, electronic data and electronic transmissions, including e-mail, are public records, unless they are specifically otherwise defined or exempted by law. Public records shall be preserve and no employee is permitted to purposely destroy or dispose of any public records in violation of the law, subpoena, court order or other legal authority. The city shall develop and implement procedures for the permanent retention and storage of public records. Those procedures may include the permanent archival or retention of public records in an alternate form, such as the scanning or printing of paper copies of e-mail. In addition, the city shall develop procedures that will (1) permit public access to public records that only exist in an electronic or nontangible form and (2) provide for the reproduction of public records that only exist in an electronic or nontangible in response to a subpoena or court order. 
Acknowledgement of Understanding 
I have read and agree to comply with the terms of this policy governing the use of the City of Bastrop computer network and technology. I understand that violation of this policy may result in disciplinary action, including possible termination and civil and criminal penalties.

(Ord. No. 08-4160, 4-10-08)

Secs. 3-2—3-19. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - MOREHOUSE MEMORIAL AIRPORT ZONING 
 
Sec. 3-20. - Definitions. 
As used in this article, unless the context otherwise requires, the following terms shall have the respective meanings ascribed to them: 
Airport: The Morehouse Memorial Airport. 
Airport elevation: The highest point of an airport's usable landing area measured in feet from mean sea level. For Morehouse Memorial Airport the established airport elevation is 167.0 feet (mean sea level). 
Airport hazard: Any structure or tree or use of land which obstructs the airspace required for, or is otherwise hazardous to, the flight of aircraft in landing or taking off at the airport; and any use of land which is hazardous to persons or property because of its proximity to the airport. 
Approach surface: A surface longitudinally centered on the extended runway centerline, extending outward and upward from each end of the primary surface and at the same slope as the approach zone height limitation slope set forth in sections 3-23 and 3-24. In plan the perimeter of the approach surface coincides with the perimeter of the approach zone. 
Approach, transitional, horizontal, and conical zones: These zones are set forth in sections 3-21 and 3-22. 
Board of appeal: A board consisting of five (5) members appointed by the governing body, as provided for in R.S. 2:386. 
Conical surface: A surface extending outward and upward from the periphery of the horizontal surface at a slope of twenty (20) to one (1) for a horizontal distance of four thousand (4,000) feet. 
Dwelling: Any building or portion thereof designed or used as a residence or sleeping place of one (1) or more persons. 
Hazard to air navigation: An obstruction determined to have a substantial adverse effect on the safe and efficient utilization of the navigable airspace. 
Height: For the purpose of determining the height limits in all zones set forth in this article and shown on the zoning map, the datum shall be mean sea level elevation unless otherwise specified. 
Horizontal surface: A horizontal plane one hundred fifty (150) feet above the established airport elevation, the perimeter of which in plan coincides with the perimeter of the horizontal zone. 
Larger than utility runway: A runway that is constructed for and intended to be used by propeller-driven aircraft of greater than twelve thousand five hundred (12,500) pounds maximum gross weight and jet-powered aircraft. 
Nonconforming use: Any pre-existing structure, object of natural growth, or use of land which is inconsistent with the provisions of this article or an amendment hereto. 
Nonprecision instrument runway: A runway having an existing instrument approach procedure utilizing air navigation facilities with only horizontal guidance, or area-type navigation equipment, for which a straight-in nonprecision instrument approach procedure has been approved, or planned, and for which no precision approach facilities are planned. 
Obstruction: Any structure, growth, or other object, including a mobile object, which exceeds a limiting height set forth in sections 3-23 and 3-24. 
Primary surface: A surface longitudinally centered on a runway. When the runway has a specially prepared hard surface, the primary surface extends two hundred (200) feet beyond each end of that runway; when the runway has no specially prepared hard surface, or planned hard surface, the primary surface ends at each end of that runway. The width of the primary surface is set forth in sections 3-21 and 3-22. The elevation of any point on the primary surface is the same as the elevation of the nearest point on the runway centerline. 
Runway: A defined area on an airport prepared for landing and takeoff of aircraft along its length. The runway includes any proposed new runway or runway extension shown on an airport layout plan or other planning document. 
Structure: An object, including a mobile object, constructed or installed by man, including, but without limitation, buildings, towers, cranes, smokestacks, earth formations, and overhead transmission lines. 
Transitional surfaces: These surfaces extend outward and upward at ninety-degree angles to the runway centerline and the runway centerline extended at a slope of seven (7) feet horizontally for each foot vertically from the sides of the primary and approach surfaces to where they intersect the horizontal and conical surfaces. 
Tree: Any object of natural growth. 
Utility runway: A runway that is constructed for and intended to be used by aircraft of twelve thousand five hundred (12,500) pounds maximum gross weight or less. 
Water surfaces: For the purpose of this article, the term shall have the same meaning as land for the establishment of protected zones. 
(Code 1966, § 25-12; Ord. No. 3234, § 2, 8-21-84)  
Sec. 3-21. - Airspace obstruction zones—Airspace zones. 
In order to carry out the provisions of this article, there are hereby created and established certain zones which include all of the land lying beneath the approach surfaces, transitional surfaces, horizontal surfaces, and conical surfaces as they apply to the airport. An area located in more than one (1) of the following zones is considered to be only in the zone with the more restrictive height limitation. The various zones are hereby established and defined as follows: 
(1)  Larger than utility runway visibility greater than three-fourths mile nonprecision instrument approach zone: The inner edge of this approach zone coincides with the width of the primary surface and is five hundred (500) feet wide. The approach zone expands outward uniformly to a width of three thousand five hundred (3,500) feet at a horizontal distance of ten thousand (10,000) feet from the primary surface. Its centerline is the continuation of the centerline of the runway. 
(2)  Transitional zones: The transitional zones are the areas beneath the transitional surfaces. 
(3)  Horizontal zone: The horizontal zone is established by swinging arcs of ten thousand (10,000) feet radii from the center of each end of the primary surface of each runway and connecting the adjacent arcs by drawing lines tangent to those arcs. The horizontal zone does not include the approach and transitional zones. 
(4)  Conical zone: The conical zone is established as the area that commences at the periphery of the horizontal zone and extends outward therefrom a horizontal distance of four thousand (4,000) feet. 
(Code 1966, § 25-13; Ord. No. 3234, § 3(A), 8-21-84)  
Sec. 3-22. - Same—Airspace zone height limitations. 
Except as otherwise provided in this article, no structure shall be erected, altered, or maintained, and no tree shall be allowed to grow in any zone created by this article to a height in excess of the applicable height limit herein established for such zone. Such applicable height limitations are hereby established for each of the zones in question as follows: 
(1)  Larger than utility runway visibility greater than three-fourths mile approach zone: (Runway 16-34) Slopes thirty-four (34) feet outward for each foot upward beginning at the end of and at the same elevation as the primary surface and extending to a horizontal distance of ten thousand (10,000) feet along the extended runway centerline. 
(2)  Transitional zones: Slopes seven (7) feet outward for each foot upward beginning at the sides of and at the same elevation as the primary surface and the approach surface, and extending to a height of one hundred fifty (150) feet above the airport elevation. In addition to the foregoing, there are established height limits sloping seven (7) feet outward for each foot upward beginning at the sides of and at the same elevation as the approach surface, and extending to where they intersect the conical surface. 
(3)  Horizontal zone: Established at one hundred fifty (150) feet above the airport elevation. 
(4)  Conical zone: Slopes twenty (20) feet outward for each foot upward beginning at the periphery of the horizontal zone and at one hundred fifty (150) feet above the airport elevation and extending horizontally four thousand (4,000) feet to a height of three hundred fifty (350) feet above the airport elevation. 
(5)  Excepted height limitations: Nothing in this article shall be construed as prohibiting the construction or maintenance of any structure, or growth of any tree to a height up to fifty (50) feet above the surface of the land. 
(Code 1966, § 25-13; Ord. No. 3234, § 3(B), 8-21-84)  
Sec. 3-23. - Land use safety zones—Created. 
In order to carry out the purpose of this article, as set forth above and also, in order to restrict those uses which may be hazardous to the operational safety of aircraft operating to and from the airport, and furthermore to limit population and building density in the runway approach areas, thereby creating sufficient open space so as to protect life and property in case of an accident, there are hereby created and established the following land use safety zones: 
(1)  Safety zone A: All land in that portion of the approach zones of a runway, as defined in section 3-21, which extends outward from the end of primary surface a distance equal to two-thirds of the planned length of the runway, which distance shall be: three thousand eight hundred (3,800) feet for runway 16-34. 
(2)  Safety zone B: All land in that portion of the approach zones of a runway, as defined in section 3-21, which extends outward from safety zone A a distance equal to one-third of the planned length of the runway, which distance shall be: one thousand nine hundred (1,900) feet for runway 16-34. 
(3)  Safety zone C: All that land which is enclosed within the perimeter of the horizontal zone, as defined in section 3-21, and which is not included in zone A or zone B. 
(Code 1966, § 25-13; Ord. No. 3234, § 4(A), 8-21-84)  
Sec. 3-24. - Same—Use restrictions. 
(a)  Zone A: Subject at all times to the height restrictions set forth in section 3-22 and to the general restrictions contained in section 3-26, areas designated as zone A shall contain no buildings, temporary structures, aerial transmission lines, or other similar aboveground land use structural hazards, and shall be restricted to those uses which will not create, attract, or bring together an assembly of persons thereon. Permitted uses may include, but are not limited to, such uses as agriculture (seasonal crops), horticulture, animal husbandry, raising of livestock, wildlife habitat, light outdoor recreation (nonspectator), cemeteries, and auto parking. 
(b)  Zone B: Subject at all times to the height restrictions set forth in section 3-22 and to the general restrictions contained in section 3-26, areas designated as zone B shall be restricted in use as follows: 
(1)  Each use shall be on a site whose area shall not be less than three (3) acres. 
(2)  Each use shall not create, attract, or bring together a site population that would exceed fifteen (15) times that of the site acreage. 
(3)  Each site shall have not more than one (1) building plot upon which any number of structures may be erected. 
(4)  A building plot shall be a single, uniform and noncontrived area, the shape of which is uncomplicated and the area of which shall not exceed the following minimum ratios with respect to the total site area:

(5)  The following uses are specifically prohibited in zone B: Churches, hospitals, schools, theaters, stadiums, hotels and motels, trailer courts, campgrounds, and other places of frequent public or semipublic assembly. 
(c)  Zone C: Zone C is subject only to height restrictions set forth in section 3-22, and to the general restrictions contained in section 3-26. 
(Code 1966, § 25-15; Ord. No. 3234, § 4(B), 8-21-84)  
Sec. 3-25. - Airport zoning map. 
The several zones herein established are shown on the Morehouse Memorial Airport Zoning Map consisting of one (1) sheet, prepared by Aillet, Fenner, Jolly & McClelland and dated January 1984, attached to the ordinance from which this article is derived and made a part hereof, which map, together with such amendments thereto as may from time to time be made, and all notations, references, elevations, data, zone boundaries, and other information thereon, shall be and the same is hereby adopted a part of this article. 
(Code 1966, § 25-13; Ord. No. 3234, § 5, 8-21-84)  
Sec. 3-26. - Use restrictions. 
Notwithstanding any other provisions of this article, no use may be made of land or water within any zone established by this article in such a manner as to create electrical interference with navigational signals or radio communication between the airport and aircraft, make it difficult for pilots to distinguish between airport lights and others, result in glare in the eyes of pilots using the airport, impair visibility in the vicinity of the airport, create bird strike hazards, or otherwise in any way endanger or interfere with the landing, takeoff, or maneuvering of aircraft intending to use the airport. 
(Code 1966, § 25-15; Ord. No. 3234, § 6, 8-21-84)  
Sec. 3-27. - Nonconforming uses—Regulations not retroactive. 
The regulations prescribed by this article shall not be construed to require the removal, lowering or other change or alteration of any structure or tree not conforming to the regulations as of the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived, or otherwise interfere with the continuance of a nonconforming use. Nothing contained herein shall require any change in the construction, alteration, or intended use of any structure, the construction or alteration of which was begun prior to the effective date of such ordinance, and was diligently prosecuted. 
(Code 1966, § 25-16; Ord. No. 3234, § 7(A), 8-21-84)  
Sec. 3-28. - Same—Marking and lighting. 
Notwithstanding the provisions of section 3-27, the owner of any existing nonconforming structure or tree is hereby required to permit the installation, operation, and maintenance thereon of such markers and lights as shall be deemed necessary by the airport owner, to indicate to the operators of aircraft in the vicinity of the airport the presence of such airport obstruction. Such markers and lights shall be installed, operated, and maintained at the expense of the airport owner. The airport owner shall also have the right to install at its cost such markers and lights, as shall be deemed necessary by the airport owner, on structures or trees which may not penetrate the horizontal or conical surfaces, but which are considered by the airport owner to be potential hazards to air navigation. 
(Code 1966, § 25-16; Ord. No. 3234, § 7(B), 8-21-84)  
Sec. 3-29. - Permits—Future uses. 
Except as specifically provided in subsections (1) and (2) hereunder, no material change shall be made in the use of land and no structure shall be erected, altered, or otherwise established in any zone hereby created unless a permit therefor shall have been applied for and granted by the city as hereinafter provided for. Each application for a permit shall indicate the purpose for which the permit is desired, with sufficient particularity to permit it to conform to the regulations herein prescribed. If such determination is in the affirmative, the permit shall be granted. A copy of each permit application when filed shall also be sent by the applicant by certified mail to the assistant secretary, office of aviation and public transportation, state department of transportation and development. 
(1)  However, a permit for a tree or structure of less than seventy-five (75) feet of vertical height above the ground shall not be required in the horizontal and conical zones or in any approach and transitional zones beyond a horizontal distance of four thousand two hundred (4,200) feet from each end of the runway except when such tree or structure, because of terrain, land contour, or topographic features, would extend above the height limit or not be of a land use prescribed for the respective zone. 
(2)  Nothing contained in this foregoing exception in subsection (1) shall be construed as permitting or intending to permit any construction, alteration, or growth of any structure or tree in excess of any of the height limitations established by this article as set forth in sections 3-23 and 3-24 or violate any land use limitation set forth in section 3-25. 
(Code 1966, § 25-17; Ord. No. 3234, § 8(A), 8-21-84)  
Sec. 3-30. - Same—Existing uses. 
No permit shall be granted that would allow the establishment or creation of an obstruction or permit a nonconforming use, structure, or tree to become a greater hazard to air navigation than it was on the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived or any amendments thereto or than it is when the application for a permit is made. Except as indicated, all applications for such a permit shall be granted. 
(Code 1966, § 25-17; Ord. No. 3234, § 8(B), 8-21-84)  
Sec. 3-31. - Same—Nonconforming uses abandoned or destroyed. 
When the city determines that a nonconforming tree or structure has been abandoned or more than eighty (80) percent torn down, physically deteriorated, or decayed, no permit shall be granted that would allow such structure or tree to exceed the applicable height limit or otherwise deviate from the zoning regulations. 
(Code 1966, § 25-17; Ord. No. 3234, § 8(C), 8-21-84)  
Sec. 3-32. - Same—Variances. 
Any person desiring to erect or increase the height of any structure, or permit the growth of any tree, or use property, not in accordance with the regulations prescribed in this article, may apply to the board of appeal for a variance from such regulations. The application for variance shall be accompanied by a determination from the federal aviation administration as to the effect of the proposal on the operation of air navigation facilities and the safe, efficient use of navigable airspace. Such variances shall be allowed where it is duly found that a literal application or enforcement of the regulations will result in unnecessary hardship and relief granted, will not be contrary to the public interest, will not create a hazard to air navigation, will do substantial justice, and will be in accordance with the spirit of this article. Additionally, no application for variance to the requirements of this article may be considered by the board of appeal unless a copy of the application has been furnished to the assistant secretary office of aviation and public transportation, state department of transportation and development and to the city for advice as to the aeronautical effects of the variance. If the city does not respond to the application within fifteen (15) days after receipt, the board of appeal may act on its own to grant or deny such application. 
(Code 1966, § 25-17; Ord. No. 3234, § 8(D), 8-21-84)  
Sec. 3-33. - Same—Obstruction marking and lighting. 
Any permit or variance granted may, if such action is deemed advisable to effectuate the purpose of this article and be reasonable in the circumstances, be so conditioned as to require the owner of the structure or tree in question to install, operate, and maintain, at the owner's expense, such markings and lights as may be necessary. If deemed property by the board of appeal, this condition may be modified to require the owner to permit the city, at its own expense, to install, operate, and maintain the necessary markings and lights. 
(Code 1966, § 25-17; Ord. No. 3234, § 8(E), 8-21-84)  
Sec. 3-34. - Enforcement. 
It shall be the duty of the city to appoint an administrative agency to administer and enforce the regulations prescribed herein. Applications for permits and variances shall be made to the administrative agency upon the form provided in Appendix A to this article for that purpose. Applications required by this article to be submitted to the administrative agency shall be promptly considered and granted or denied. Application for action by the board of appeal shall be forthwith transmitted by the administrative agency. 
(Code 1966, § 25-18; Ord. No. 3234, § 9, 8-21-84)  
Sec. 3-35. - Board of appeal—Created; powers; members; organization; meetings. 
(a)  There is hereby created a board of appeal, to have and exercise the following powers: 
(1)  To hear and decide appeals from any order, requirement, decision, or determination made by the administrative agency in the enforcement of this article or any ordinance adopted pursuant hereto; 
(2)  To hear and decide special exceptions to the terms of this article upon which such board may be required to pass under this article or ordinance; 
(3)  To hear and decide specific variances under R.S. 2:385(B), where a zoning board of appeals or adjustment already exists, it may be appointed as the board of appeal. Otherwise, the board of appeal shall consist of five (5) members, each to be appointed for a term of three (3) years and to be removable for cause by the appointing authority upon written charges and after public hearing. 
(b)  The board shall adopt rules in accordance with the provisions of this article or any ordinance adopted hereunder. Meetings of the board shall be held at the call of the chairman and at such other times as the board may determine. The chairman, or in the chairman's absence the acting chairman, may administer oaths and compel the attendance of witnesses. All meetings of the board shall be public. The board shall keep minutes of its proceedings, showing the vote of each member upon each question, or, if absent or failing to vote, indicating such fact, and shall keep records of its examinations and other official actions, all of which shall immediately be filed in the office of the board and shall be a public record. 
(Code 1966, § 25-19; Ord. No. 3234, § 10(A), (B), 8-21-84)  
Sec. 3-36. - Same—Appeal procedure; effect; hearing. 
(a)  Appeals to the board of appeal may be taken by any person aggrieved, or by any officer, department, board, or bureau of the political subdivision affected, by any decision of the administrative agency. An appeal must be taken within a reasonable time, as provided by the rules of the board, by filing with the agency from which the appeal is taken and with the board, a notice of appeal specifying the grounds thereof. The agency from which the appeal is taken shall forthwith transmit to the board all the papers constituting the record upon which the action appealed from was taken. 
(b)  An appeal shall stay all proceedings in furtherance of the action appealed from, unless the agency from which the appeal is taken certifies to the board, after the notice of appeal has been filed with it, that by reason of the facts stated in the certificate a stay would, in its opinion, cause imminent peril to life or property. In such case proceedings shall not be stayed otherwise than by a restraining order which may be granted by the board or by a court of record on application on notice to the agency from which the appeal is taken and on due cause shown. 
(c)  The board shall fix a reasonable time for the hearing of the appeal, give public notice and due notice to the parties in interest, and decide the same within a reasonable time. Upon the hearing any party may appear in person or by agent or by attorney. 
(Code 1966, § 25-18; Ord. No. 3234, § 10(C)—(E), 8-21-84)  
Sec. 3-37. - Same—Action. 
(a)  The board of appeal may reverse or affirm, wholly or partly, or modify, the order, requirement, decision, or determination appealed from and may make such order, requirement, decision, or determination as ought to be made, and to that end shall have all the powers of the administrative agency from which the appeal is taken. 
(b)  The concurring vote of a majority of the members of the board shall be sufficient to reverse any order, requirement, decision, or determination of the administrative agency, or to decide the favor of the applicant on any matter upon which it is required to pass under any such ordinance, or to effect any variation in this article or such ordinance. 
(Code 1966, § 25-19; Ord. No. 3234, § 10(F), (G), 8-21-84)  
Sec. 3-38. - Judicial review. 
Any person aggrieved, or any taxpayer affected, by any decision of the board of appeal, may appeal to the district court as provided in R.S. 2:387. 
(Code 1966, § 25-20; Ord. No. 3234, § 11, 8-21-84)  
Sec. 3-39. - Conflicting regulations. 
Where there exists a conflict between any of the regulations or limitations prescribed in this article and any other regulations applicable to the same area, whether the conflict be with respect to the height of structures or trees, or the use of the land, or any other matter, the more stringent limitation or requirement shall govern and prevail. 
(Ord. No. 3234, § 13, 8-21-84)  
Chapter 4 - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Entering establishment with firearm, § 8-154. 
 
Sec. 4-1. - Definitions. 
For the purposes of this chapter, the following terms shall have the respective meanings ascribed to them in this section, except in those instances where the context indicates a different meaning: 
Alcoholic beverages: Any fluid, or any solid capable of being converted into fluid, suitable for human consumption, and containing more than one-half (½) of one (1) percent of alcohol by volume, including malt, vinous, spirituous, alcoholic or intoxicating liquors, beers, porter, ale, stout, fruit juices, cider, and wine. 
(1)  Beverages of low alcoholic content: Alcoholic beverages containing not more than six (6) percent of alcohol by volume. 
(2)  Beverages of high alcoholic content: Alcoholic beverages containing more than six (6) percent of alcohol by volume. 
Beer outlet: A place where any person draws or removes any malt beverages from containers for consumption on or off the premises. 
Bottle club: Any establishment whereby the owner, or any employee of the owner, does not sell, serve, handle, dispense or store alcoholic beverages, but in which patrons are allowed to consume alcoholic beverages on the premises from the patron's own store, stock, or supplies of alcoholic beverages. 
Class A beer retail dealer: Any person who sells alcoholic beverages of low alcoholic content at retail for consumption on or off the premises. 
Class B beer dealer: Any person who sells alcoholic beverages of low alcoholic content at retail in bottles, cans or other sealed containers only and only for consumption off the licensed premises. 
Class A liquor retail dealer: Any person who sells alcoholic beverages of high or low alcoholic content at retail in bottles, cans or other sealed containers and only for consumption off the licensed premises. 
Class A (retail dealer, off premises only): Any person who sells beverages of high or low alcoholic content at retail in sealed containers for consumption off the licensed premises. 
Class B (retail dealer, on premises): Any person who sells beverages of high or low alcoholic content at retail for consumption on the premises, or in sealed containers (eg., bottles and cans) for consumption off the promises. 
Class D liquor retail dealer: Any person who sells alcoholic beverages of high or low alcoholic content, including frozen drinks, at retail in sealed containers with a closed top or cap, even though temporary in nature, and only for consumption off the licensed premises. 
Class R restaurant establishment: Any restaurant establishment that sells alcohol of high and low alcohol content at retail for consumption on the premises. 
Consumption off the licensed premises : In a closed container, prepared for transportation and actual consumption of the beverage other than on the licensed premises. A beverage covered or sealed with a closed top or cap, even though temporary in nature, shall be considered as a closed container. 
Dealer: Any person who, as a business, manufactures, blends, rectifies, distills, processes, imports, stores, uses, handles, holds, sells, offers for sale, solicits orders for the sale of, distributes, delivers, serves, or transports any alcoholic beverage in the city or engages herein in any business transaction relating to any such beverage. 
Handle: To sell, use, distribute, store, consume, or otherwise handle. 
Hotel-motel hospitality room: Any room in a bona fide hotel or motel which is used for the purpose of the hospitable consumption of alcoholic beverages. 
License or permit: Used interchangeably. 
Manufacturer: Any person who directly or indirectly, personally or through any agency, engages in the making, blending, rectifying, or other processing of alcoholic beverages in the city. 
Package house: A place where a person sells alcoholic beverages in closed containers, prepared for transportation and consumption off the premises. 
Premises: A licensed establishment where alcoholic beverages are kept, sold, stored, or consumed. 
Private club: An organization with limited and restricted membership which is nonprofit in nature and classified as tax exempt by all state and federal taxing authorities. 
Restaurant establishment: An entity which operates a place of business whose purpose and primary function is to take orders for, prepare and serve food and food items on the premises, which serves alcoholic beverages in conjunction with meals, which serves food on all days of operation, which grosses sixty (60) percent of its average monthly revenue from the sale of food and food items, which maintains separate sales figures for alcoholic beverages, and which operates a fully equipped kitchen used for the preparation of uncooked foods for service and consumption of such food on the premises. 
Retail dealer: Any person who offers for sale, exposes for sale, has in such person's possession for sale or distribution, or sells, alcoholic beverages in any quantity to persons other than licensed wholesale or retail dealers. 
Wholesale dealer: Any person who sells alcoholic beverages to licensed wholesale dealers or licensed retail dealers within the city, or to any person for delivery beyond the borders of the city. 
(Code 1966, § 4-1; Ord. No. 3134, § 1, 12-14-82; Ord. No. 01-3937, § 1, 5-10-01; Ord. No. 05-4053, 4-14-05; Ord. No. 05-4076, 11-10-05) 
State Law reference— For definitions under the state beverage laws, see R.S. 26:2, 26:241, 26:581, 26:641, 26:711.  
Sec. 4-2. - License required, exception; prior payment of fee before issuance; high content license includes low content license. 
(a)  Every retail dealer and every wholesale dealer in alcoholic beverages of low alcoholic content or alcoholic beverages of high alcoholic content and any private club or bottle club is hereby required to obtain from the city for each year, an appropriate license to conduct such business during each year in which such business is to be conducted, the issuance of which shall be conditioned upon the prior payment of the license fees levied in section 4-13. A license to sell alcoholic beverages of high alcoholic content shall include, and obviate the necessity of, a license to sell alcoholic beverages of low alcoholic content. 
(b)  Any hotel/motel hospitality room shall be exempt from the licensing requirements set forth above. 
(c)  In addition to the other requirements set forth in subsection (a), an applicant for a restaurant establishment class R license shall attach to its application: 
(1)  Proof of issuance of a retail dealer's license for on-premises consumption of alcoholic beverages (of high or low content) from the city (or contemporaneous application for such license); and 
(2)  An affidavit establishing that the applicant is a restaurant establishment and the establishment grosses sixty (60) percent of its average monthly revenue from the sale of food and food items, which affidavit is supported by copies of actual business records, including sales records, sales tax receipts, receipts for purchases of food, food items and alcoholic beverages. 
(d)  For new restaurant establishments without prior business experience on which to determine the gross revenue from the sale of the items as set forth in subsection (c)(2) above, the affidavit provided in subsection (c)(2) shall provide that based upon the reasonable expectation of applicant, the establishment will meet the requirement, and the restaurant establishment class R license granted shall be considered as temporary and shall be subject to the express condition that the necessary documentation as set forth in subsection (c)(2) above shall be submitted prior to the expiration of a sixty-day period from the grant of the license, or the license shall automatically expire. 
(e)  Failure of an establishment to continue to meet the requirements of a "restaurant establishment" shall be sufficient grounds for immediate suspension of the restaurant establishment class R license. 
(f)  If an applicant for a restaurant establishment class R license is the holder of a retail dealer's license for on-premises consumption of alcoholic beverages from the city, the city may issue the restaurant establishment class R license upon compliance with this section, and without additional approval of the city council. 
(Code 1966, §§ 4-2, 4-2.1; Ord. No. 3134, § 1, 12-14-82; Ord. No. 01-3937, § 2, 5-10-01)  
Sec. 4-3. - License prerequisite to engaging in business; posting. 
(a)  No person shall engage in either of the businesses of selling, offering for sale, possessing for sale, or allowing the consumption of or distribution of alcoholic beverages of low alcoholic content or alcoholic beverages of high alcoholic content without first obtaining the necessary license required hereunder. 
(b)  All licenses issued hereunder must be posted in a conspicuous place in the licensed premises. 
(Code 1966, § 4-3; Ord. No. 3134, § 1, 12-14-82)  
Sec. 4-4. - Governing body to determine issuance; certificate of approval. 
The right to determine which persons shall or shall not be issued licenses hereunder shall be vested in the governing body. No license hereunder, whether new or renewal, shall be issued by the city tax collector unless such collector has received a certificate evidencing the approval of the application for a license by the governing body. 
(Code 1966, § 4-4; Ord. No. 3134, § 1, 12-14-82)  
Sec. 4-5. - Sale by wholesaler only when retailer's license displayed; exceptions. 
No wholesale dealer shall sell to any retail dealer any alcoholic beverage unless the retail dealer has posted in a conspicuous place in such retail dealer's establishment the license required hereunder; provided, a wholesale dealer may sell such beverages to a retail dealer commencing a new business, or buying or taking over an established business for which a license has been issued, if such retail dealer produces a certificate from the tax collector of the city dated not more than thirty-five (35) days prior to the sale of alcoholic beverages, evidencing the application for a license or permit hereunder. 
(Code 1966, § 4-5; Ord. No. 3134, § 1, 12-14-82)  
Sec. 4-6. - Separate license required; transferability; changing locations. 
(a)  Separate licenses shall be required for each place of business operated by a retail dealer, wholesale dealer, bottle club, or private club. All licenses issued hereunder shall be personal and nontransferable, and shall become void upon the death of the licensee. If the business changes hands during the period for which the license was issued, a new license shall be applied for and paid to the tax collector within fifteen (15) calendar days of the date of change. Upon the failure of the original licensee to notify the tax collector for any such change in the license within the fifteen-calendar-day period, the original licensee shall be assessed ten dollars ($10.00) per day for each day of noncompliance. 
(b)  A retail dealer or wholesale dealer shall conduct such business only in the licensed premises, which premises shall include the lot of the licensee, but shall exclude the sidewalk, street curb, and street adjacent thereto, and no license issued hereunder shall authorize the conducting of business in any changed location except upon application therefor submitted to the governing body, which may grant or deny it as it deems advisable. Should the location of the place of business be changed or should there be any other change in the requirements of the original license during the period the license runs, such license shall be sent to the tax collector within fifteen (15) calendar days of the date of change so that the proper changes may be noted thereon. The tax collector shall collect from the licensee requesting the change, an administrative fee of ten (10) percent of the license fee or a minimum of twenty dollars ($20.00), whichever is greater, for any such license change. Upon the failure of the licensee requesting the change to notify the tax collector of any such change within the fifteen-calendar-day period, the licensee shall be assessed an additional ten dollars ($10.00) per day for each day of noncompliance. 
(c)  The license shall at all times be prominently displayed by the dealer in such dealer's place of business so as to be seen and easily read by the public. 
(d)  The premises for which licenses shall be issued within the meaning of this chapter are as defined in section 4-1, but the premises shall not include the sidewalk, street curb, or street adjacent thereto. 
(Code 1966, § 4-6; Ord. No. 3134, § 1, 12-14-82) 
State Law reference— As to personal nature of permit, see R.S. 26:76, 26:276.  
Sec. 4-7. - Refusal to issue license; revocation. 
In the exercise of its police power, whenever deemed advisable and for the general welfare, under this chapter or any applicable law of the state of Louisiana, the governing body may for good cause, revoke any permit previously issued. If any retail dealer has conducted, operated, or permitted, such dealer's place of business so as to become a dive, disorderly place, or nuisance, any application for the renewal of the license or permit hereunder may be refused. 
(Code 1966, § 4-7; Ord. No. 3134, § 1, 12-14-82) 
State Law reference— Suspension or revocation of permits by municipality, R.S. 33:4785 et seq.  
Sec. 4-8. - Ineligibility of spouse to obtain license. 
No license shall be issued to any applicant who is the spouse of a person who personally is ineligible for a permit, unless such applicant is legally separated from such spouse. In the event the spouse and such person resume living together as spouses of each other, the licensee must return the license issued to such licensee to the tax collector within fifteen (15) days after resumption of living with the spouse. Upon the failure of such licensee to comply with this section, the licensee shall be deemed in violation of this chapter and shall be subject to the penalties provided in section 1-8. 
(Code 1966, § 4-7.1; Ord. No. 3134, § 1, 12-14-82)  
Sec. 4-9. - License application—Filing; delinquency penalty. 
(a)  All applications for licenses for a new business shall be filed with the tax collector. 
(b)  Applications for renewals for a license shall be filed with the tax collector on or before the thirty-first day of October for the ensuing year. 
(c)  Should any retail dealer, wholesale dealer, bottle club, restaurant or private club fail to file an application for the renewal of a license for the ensuing year on or before the thirty-first day of October, a delinquency penalty shall be imposed of five (5) percent of the amount due for the license applied for if the failure is for not more than thirty (30) days, with an additional five (5) percent for each additional thirty (30) days or fraction thereof during which the failure continues. If the application for the renewal of a license is not filed until on or after January first of the year for which the license is required, the application may be denied. 
(d)  Renewal licenses may be withheld or denied on the same grounds and in the same manner as an original license. 
(Code 1966, § 4-8; Ord. No. 3134, § 1, 12-14-82; Ord. No. 01-3937, § 3, 5-10-01) 
State Law reference— Similar provision as to penalty, R.S. 26:88, 26:285.  
Sec. 4-10. - Same—Requirements; stamping; submitting to officers for investigation; submitting to governing body. 
(a)  All applications for new or renewal licenses shall be in writing, shall be sworn to before an officer authorized to administer oaths, and shall contain the information and shall be accompanied by the documents set forth and detailed in section 4-12. 
(b)  The tax collector shall immediately stamp upon each application the year, month and day on which it was received, and shall deliver the application to the chief of police, who shall immediately make an investigation of the applicant and of the applicant's character and reputation, and if the applicant is a partnership, an investigation as to the character and reputation of each member thereof, and if the applicant is a corporation, the same investigation of each officer and manager of such corporation. When the investigation is completed, a written statement of the results thereof shall be made and filed with the tax collector, who in turn shall submit it to the mayor and to the governing body. 
(Code 1966, § 4-9; Ord. No. 3134, § 1, 12-14-82) 
State Law reference— For similar provisions as to state permit, see R.S. 26:78, 26:278.  
Sec. 4-11. - Same—Qualifications of applicant. 
(a)  Every applicant for an alcoholic beverage license shall meet the following qualifications and conditions: 
(1)  Is a person of good character and reputation and over twenty-one (21) years of age. 
(2)  Is a citizen of the United States and of the state and a resident of the state continuously for a period of not less than two (2) years next preceding the date of filing the application. 
(3)  Is the owner of the premises or has a bona fide written lease therefor. In cases where the applicant holds a bona fide written lease, the name and current address of the lessor shall be shown on the application form filed with the tax collector. 
(4)  Has not been convicted of a felony under the laws of the United States, this state, or any other state or country. 
(5)  Has not been convicted in this or in any other state or by the United States or any other country of soliciting for prostitution, pandering, letting premises for prostitution, contributing to the delinquency of juveniles, keeping a disorderly place, letting a disorderly place, or illegally dealing in narcotics. 
(6)  Has not had a license or permit to sell or deal in alcoholic beverages, issued by the United States, by any state, or by any municipality or other political subdivision of any state authorized to issue permits or licenses with respect to alcoholic beverages, revoked within two (2) years prior to the application, or been convicted or had a judgment of court rendered against such person in a case involving alcoholic beverages by the courts of the city or any other political subdivision, or the state or any other state or the United States for two (2) years prior to the application. 
(7)  Has not been adjudged by any alcoholic beverage control board of this state to have violated, or been convicted by any court of violating, any of the provisions of this chapter or of the alcoholic beverage control laws or ordinances of any other state or political subdivision. 
(b)  If the applicant is a partnership, or anyone in partnership with or financed by another, all members of the partnership or all the persons in any way financially interested in the business shall also possess the qualifications required of an applicant. The application shall state the full names and proper residence addresses of all partners and persons financially interested, and each shall furnish such person's affidavit showing such person's qualifications, as required of an applicant. 
(c)  If the applicant is a corporation, it shall be either organized under the laws of this state or qualified to do business within this state, and, all officers and directors and all stockholders owning in the aggregate more than five (5) percent of the stock and the persons who shall conduct or manage the business shall possess the qualifications required of an applicant, to be shown by the affidavit of each accompanying the application. 
(d)  If the applicant's business is to be conducted wholly or partly by one (1) or more managers, agents, servants, employees or other representatives, those persons shall also possess the qualifications required of the applicant, to be shown by the affidavit of each accompanying the application. 
(e)  If the applicant, or any person required to have the same qualifications, does not possess the required qualifications, the license may be denied. 
(Code 1966, § 4-10; Ord. No. 3134, § 1, 12-14-82; Ord. No. 93-3648, § 1, 1-11-93; Ord. No. 99-3863, 1-14-99) 
State Law reference— For similar provisions, see R.S. 26:80, 26:280.  
Sec. 4-12. - Same—Contents; fingerprinting of applicant; advertisement of new application. 
(a)  Every application for a license to engage in the sale at retail or wholesale of alcoholic beverages shall set forth and contain the following: 
(1)  The full name of the applicant, correct home address of applicant and an accurate description and the correct address of the premises wherein the business is to be conducted, which latter address shall be considered the proper address for all notices to the applicant required by this chapter or by the state law. 
(2)  The year, month, day and place of applicant's birth. If the birth of the applicant occurred outside the United States, the applicant shall declare, if true, that applicant is a naturalized citizen of the United States and shall attach to the application a certificate of the clerk of court wherein the naturalization occurred, showing the applicant was naturalized, and give the date of the order or judgment granting such naturalization. If such information cannot be set forth in any printed form which may be furnished, then it shall be set forth in a sworn statement which the applicant shall attach to the application. 
(3)  A statement, if true, that the applicant has continuously resided in this state for two (2) years prior to the filing of the application. 
(4)  A statement that the applicant is the owner of the premises to be licensed or has a bona fide written lease therefor, in which latter event the name of the lessor shall be shown in the application and a duplicate original or certified copy of such lease shall be filed by the applicant with the application. 
(5)  A statement that the applicant has not been charged with or convicted of a felony or misdemeanor under the laws of the United States, this state or any other state of the country, or under the ordinances of this city or any other municipality or political subdivision; or, if such convictions or charges have occurred, a complete list thereof, including the name of the court, the state and city or parish or county where each charge was made, the nature of each charge and the disposition thereof (i.e., conviction and sentence received, dismissal without trial, acquittal or pending). 
(6)  A statement that no alcoholic beverage license or permit issued to the applicant or a partnership in which applicant was a partner or a corporation in which applicant was an officer, director or stockholder owning more than five (5) percent of the stock has been revoked within five (5) years prior to the filing of the application, and that no conviction by any court or adverse judgment against applicant, or a partnership or corporation in which applicant was interested as aforesaid, with respect to alcoholic beverages has ever occurred; or if any such revocation or conviction has occurred, a full and complete disclosure regarding the same shall be made a part of the application and sworn to by the applicant. 
(7)  If the application is for a new business and is not for the renewal of a license which has theretofore been issued to applicant and which has not been revoked, then the applicant for such new license shall attach to the application a separate document (if no space is provided therefor in the application form), which shall be sworn to before an officer authorized to administer oaths, showing the following: 
a.  The cities, towns and places in the United States where applicant has lived. Applicant shall give, if possible, the names of the streets and the numbers thereof of each place where applicant has resided. 
b.  The work in which applicant has been engaged for the ten (10) years preceding the date of applicant's application, with full details and particulars. 
c.  Whether applicant has ever been known by any name other than the name given in the application. If so, applicant shall give the names under which applicant has been known or the name which applicant has assumed and the places where such name has been used. 
d.  Whether applicant has ever conducted a house of prostitution or been interested in any way or manner in the operation of such place, and whether applicant has been convicted of violating the "white slave law." 
e.  Whether applicant has sold or possessed for sale narcotics of any kind, or whether applicant is an alcoholic or a user of dope or narcotics. 
f.  The places where applicant has operated saloons or cocktail lounges or other places where alcoholic beverages were sold; the places where applicant has worked in bars or lounges, either as a bartender or in any other capacity. 
(b)  In order to carry out its duty to properly investigate all applicants for alcoholic beverage licenses, the police department may require any applicant to submit to a fingerprinting test in order that applicant's background may be checked. Failure to submit to such a test on request of the police department shall be grounds for the denial, suspension or revocation of any alcoholic beverage license. 
(c)  Each applicant for a license to conduct a new business shall give notice in the official journal of the city that applicant is applying in the city for a license to engage in the sale of alcoholic beverages in the city, and shall attach to such application a certificate by the publisher of the official journal that such notice has been published for the period required by law. 
(d)  Any misstatement, concealment or suppression of fact in any application or accompanying affidavit or document shall be sufficient ground for the denial, suspension or revocation of a permit. 
(Code 1966, § 4-10.1; Ord. No. 3134, § 1, 12-14-82)  
Sec. 4-13 - License fees—Schedule. 
There is hereby levied an annual license fee against all who may engage in the business of selling, either retail or wholesale, offering for sale, serving or consuming alcoholic beverages in the city. The fees are assessed as follows: 
(1)  Class A (retail dealer, off premises only) ..... $ 400.00 
(2)  Class A—Beer only (retail dealer, off premises only) ..... 60.00 
(3)  Class B (retail dealer, on premises) ..... 500.00 
(4)  Class B—Beer only (retail dealer, on premises) ..... 75.00 
(5)  Class B (private club, on premises only) ..... 500.00 
(6)  Class R (restaurant) ..... 500.00 
(7)  Wholesale liquor dealer ..... 500.00 
(Code 1966, § 4-11; Ord. No. 3134, § 1, 12-14-82; Ord. No. 89-3961, § 1, 10-12-89; Ord. No. 92-3591, § 1, 8-18-92; Ord. No. 01-3937, § 4, 5-10-01; Ord. No 05-4053, 4-14-05; Ord. No. 05-4076, 11-10-05) 
State Law reference— Authority to collect, R.S. 26:74, 26:274.  
Sec. 4-14. - Same—Full fee regardless of date of commencing business. 
In the event a business shall commence subsequent to the first day of January of any year a full year's license fee shall be collected regardless of time of commencement. 
(Code 1966, § 4-12; Ord. No. 3134, § 1, 12-14-82)  
Sec. 4-14.1. - Same—Exemptions for hotel/motel hospitality rooms, restaurants. 
The closing hours as set forth in section 4-14 shall not apply to hotel/motel hospitality rooms or restaurants that hold a Class R restaurant alcohol license. Restaurants that have a Class R restaurant alcohol license may not sell alcoholic beverages or permit the consumption of alcoholic beverages on their premises from 12:00 midnight on Saturday until 10:00 a.m. on Sunday, and from 10:00 p.m. on Sunday until 6:00 a.m. on the following Monday morning, and are permitted to sell beer, wine and like beverages containing not more than six (6) percent of alcohol by volume in conjunction with meals prepared and served on the premises on Sundays between the hours of 10:00 a.m. and 10:00 p.m. 
(Ord. No. 06-4081, 2-9-06)  
Sec. 4-15. - Federal and state licenses and permits required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, keep, or offer for sale, any alcoholic beverage defined in this chapter without first obtaining from the United States and the state every license and permit, if any, authorizing such person to engage as dealer in intoxicating liquors defined by the United States and the state. 
(Code 1966, § 4-13; Ord. No. 3134, § 1, 12-14-82)  
Sec. 4-15.1. - Requirement to display sign; fetal alcohol syndrome. 
(a)  Each person holding a license under the provisions of this chapter shall post and display in a conspicuous place on each licensed premises a sign which shall clearly read as follows: 
"WARNING: 
DRINKING ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES DURING PREGNANCY CAN CAUSE SEVERE PHYSICAL OR MENTAL BIRTH DEFECTS." 
(b)  Signs required to be posted or displayed herein shall not be less than eight (8) inches by ten (10) inches with letters not less than three-eighths ( 3/8 ) of an inch in height. Said signs must be substantially similar in design and color as the sample attached to this section, by reference, and available for inspection at the office of the city clerk of the City of Bastrop. 
(c)  The city may make such warning signs available to licensees under this chapter. 
(d)  Any licensee or permittee who shall violate the provisions of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be punished by a fine of not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00), or in default thereof, twenty (20) days in jail, or both, upon the first conviction and not more than two hundred dollars ($200.00) or forty (40) days in jail or both upon the second or subsequent convictions. In the case of a corporation, the officer or agent in and upon conviction may be punished as provided above. 
(Ord. No. 94-3662, § 1, 5-27-94) 
Editor's note— Section 1 of Ord. No. 94-3662, adopted May 27, 1994, provided for the addition of a new § 4-15. Inasmuch as provisions designated as such already existed in this Code, said new section has been added herein as § 4-15.1 at the editor's discretion.  
Sec. 4-16. - Closing hours—Specified. 
All places of business where alcoholic beverages are kept, sold, stored for sale at retail, or served shall make no sale of, serve or dispense any alcoholic beverage between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 6:00 a.m. Monday through Saturday, and between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 12:00 noon on Sunday. During the hours when the sale of alcohol is prohibited, all activity at any business where alcohol is sold for consumption on the premises shall cease. All places of business where alcoholic beverages are sold for consumption on the premises, or where consumption on the premises without sale is permitted, may remain open solely to permit consumption on the premises, but shall not sell, serve or dispense alcohol, between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 2:00 a.m. on Saturday, Sunday and on the following holidays: New Year's Day, Independence Day, Labor Day, Thanksgiving Day, and Christmas Day. 
(Code 1966, § 4-14; Ord. No. 3134, § 1, 12-14-82; Ord. No. 89-3435, § 1, 5-11-89; Ord. No. 95-3733, § 1, 11-21-95; Ord. No. 12-4208, 6-14-12; Ord. No. 13-4221, 12-12-13 ; Ord. No. 16-4240 , 5-12-16)  
Sec. 4-16.1. - Establishments holding R permits exempt. 
The provisions contained in section 4-16 shall not apply to any restaurant that holds a Class R restaurant alcohol license as defined in section 4-13. 
(Ord. No. 06-4081, 2-9-06)  
Sec. 4-17. - Same—Exemptions of hotel-motel hospitality rooms and bottle clubs. 
In addition, the closing hour set forth in section 4-16 shall not apply to restaurant establishments; however, restaurant establishments may not sell or serve alcoholic beverages between the hours of 1:00 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. Monday through Friday, and between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. on Saturday and Sunday. 
(Code 1966, § 4-14.1; Ord. No. 3134, § 1, 12-14-82; Ord. No. 3825, 3-12-98; Ord. No. 01-3937, § 5, 5-10-01; Ord. No. 13-4221, 12-12-13 )  
Sec. 4-18. - Same—Exemption of private clubs. 
A bona fide private club, a bottle club, or the premises of a commercial establishment wherein alcoholic beverages are dispensed or consumed at a privately controlled function shall not dispense or permit the consumption of alcoholic beverages between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 6:00 a.m. on Monday through Friday, and between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. on Saturday and Sunday, but shall otherwise be exempt from the closing hour set forth in section 4-16. Notwithstanding any declaration made herein that is to the contrary, a bona fide bottle club may remain open and permit the consumption of alcoholic beverages between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 2:00 a.m. on the following holidays: New Year's Day, Independence Day, Labor Day, Thanksgiving Day and Christmas Day. 
(Code 1966, § 4-14.2; Ord. No. 3134, § 1, 12-14-82; Ord. No. 3825, 3-12-98; Ord. No. 3830, 5-14-98; Ord. No. 99-3899, 12-9-99; Ord. No. 02-3987, § 1, 11-14-02; Ord. No. 03-4002, §§ 1, 2, 6-12-03; Ord. No. 13-4221, 12-12-13 )  
Sec. 4-19. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 12-4208, adopted June 14, 2012, repealed § 4-19, which pertained to establishments holding R permits exempt—exceptions, merchandise to be concealed during such hours and derived from § 4-15 of the 1966 Code; Ord. No. 3134, § 1, 12-14-82.  
Sec. 4-20. - Same—Frequenting places during such times. 
It shall be unlawful for any person, other than the proprietor or the proprietor's employee, to stay or be found in any place where alcoholic beverages are kept and sold between the hours such places are required to be closed. 
(Code 1966, § 4-16; Ord. No. 3134, § 1, 12-14-82)  
Sec. 4-21. - Sale in dwellings. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, offer for sale, or keep for sale, any alcoholic beverage controlled by this chapter in any place or premises used as a dwelling house, a boardinghouse, a lodginghouse, or a rooming house; provided, nothing in this section shall apply to duly licensed hotels. 
(Code 1966, § 4-17; Ord. No. 3134, § 1, 12-14-82)  
Sec. 4-22. - Sleeping in premises. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to lie or sleep on the counter, tables, chairs or floor or other place in any place wherein alcoholic beverages are kept and sold. 
(Code 1966, § 4-18; Ord. No. 3134, § 1, 12-14-82)  
Sec. 4-23. - Proximity to schools, churches, etc. 
(a)  No license as defined in section 4-2 shall be granted for any premises situated within three hundred (300) feet or less, as fixed by the ordinance, of a public playground or of a building used exclusively as a church or synagogue, public library, school, or full-time day care center as defined in R.S. 17:405(A)(4). 
(b)  In respect to beverages of high alcoholic content and low alcoholic content, the measurement of this distance shall be measured as a person walks using the sidewalk from the nearest point of the property line of the church, synagogue, public library, public playground, or school to the nearest point of the public premises to be licensed, or by such method as may hereafter be prescribed by the laws of the state. 
(c)  The restrictions contained in this section do not apply to premises which are maintained as bona fide hotel, motel, railway car, or fraternal organization, nor to any premises licensed to deal in alcoholic beverages for one (1) year prior to the effective date of the ordinance from which this section is derived. 
(d)  That in the event a retail or wholesale business has an interruption of the continuity of business for a period in excess of six (6) months, in order to reopen for business, the requirements set forth above in subsection (a) of this section must be complied with. 
(e)  Any manufacturing, wholesale or retail business exempted from the coverage of subsection (a) of this section by the applicability of subsection (c) of this section, or any city, state or federal statutory or constitutional provision shall be so exempted or protected only to the extent of the class of license issued legally permitted to be on the premises as of the date that the public playground or building used exclusively as a church or synagogue, public library, or school began operation. 
(Code 1966, § 4-19; Ord. No. 3134, § 1, 12-14-82; Ord. No. 93-3645, § 1, 10-14-93; Ord. No. 05-4049, 2-10-05) 
State Law reference— Authority, R.S. 26:81, 26:281.  
Sec. 4-23.1. - Security at establishments where alcohol is dispensed or consumed. 
Every establishment licensed by the city to dispense alcohol, or to permit the consumption of alcohol upon its premises, shall employ security personnel and only such persons certified by the Council on Peace Officer Standards and Training ("P.O.S.T. Certification") to carry firearms and who are commissioned as law enforcement officers to arrest individuals within the corporate limits of the city who are suspected of violating crimes enumerated in the city's Code of Ordinances or in the Louisiana Criminal Code, when such establishment is open and permits the sale, dispensing or consumption of alcohol on its premises after 12:00 midnight. Not less than two (2) P.O.S.T. certified security personnel commissioned to make arrests in the city shall be posted on such premises during the period from 12:00 midnight until the premises are closed. 
(Ord. No. 99-3899, 12-9-99; Ord. No. 13-4221, 12-12-13 ) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 99-3899, adopted Dec. 9, 1999, amended the Code by adding provisions designated as § 4-24. Inasmuch as there were already provisions so designated, the provisions have been redesignated as § 4-23.1, at the discretion of the editor.  
Sec. 4-24. - Reservation of rights to governing body. 
The city reserves all rights that it might have under existing state laws relative to the issuance and revocation of permits. 
(Code 1966, § 4-20; Ord. No. 3134, § 1, 12-14-82)  
Sec. 4-25. - Unlawful acts on licensed premises.
