State Law reference— Peddler's license, R.S. 47:359(C).  
Sec. 13-3. - Insurance business. 
(a)  On any insurer engaged in the business of issuing life or accident or health insurance policies or other forms of contracts or obligations covering such risks, or issuing endowment or annuity policies, or contracts, or other similar forms of contract obligations in consideration of the payment of a premium or other consideration for the issuance of such policies, contracts or obligations whether such insurer by operating in this state or through an agent or other representative or otherwise, ten dollars ($10.00) on gross annual premiums up to two thousand dollars ($2,000.00) and an additional license thereafter of seventy dollars ($70.00) on each ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00), or fraction thereof, of gross annual premiums in excess of two thousand dollars ($2,000.00). The maximum license on such businesses, payable to this municipality by any one (1) insurer, shall not exceed twenty-one thousand dollars ($21,000.00). 
(b)  On any insurer, engaged in the business of issuing policies, contracts or other forms of obligations covering the risk of fire, marine, transportation, surety, fidelity, indemnity, guaranty, worker's compensation, employers' liability, property damage, live stock, vehicle, automatic sprinkler, burglary, or insurance business of any other kind whatsoever in this state, whether such insurer is operating in this state through agents or other representative or otherwise, shall be as allowed by the aforementioned statutes, as follows: 
1st Class: When the gross receipts are not more than two thousand dollars ($2,000.00), the license shall be forty dollars ($40.00). 
2nd Class: When the gross receipts are more than two thousand dollars ($2,000.00), and not more than four thousand dollars ($4,000.00), the license shall be sixty dollars ($60.00). 
3rd Class: When the gross receipts are more than four thousand dollars ($4,000.00), and not more than six thousand dollars ($6,000.00), the license shall be eighty dollars ($80.00). 
4th Class: When the gross receipts exceed six thousand dollars ($6,000.00), the additional license thereafter shall be seventy dollars ($70.00) for each ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00), or fraction thereof, in excess of six thousand dollars ($6,000.00). 
(c)  The maximum license tax on such businesses, payable to this municipality by any insurer, shall not exceed the maximum limit of nine thousand dollars ($9,000.00), as provided for by R.S. 22:1076, above referred to; provided, that plate glass and steam boiler inspection insurers shall pay one one-third of the above rates provided in subsection (b); and provided further, that the amount of license payable to this municipality as fixed by this section, shall be one-third of the amount so fixed if the payer shall file a sworn statement with the annual report required by R.S. Title 22, Chapter 1, Part XXIII, showing that at least one-sixtieth of the total admitted assets of the payer, less assets in an amount equal to the reserves on its policies issued in foreign countries in which it is authorized to do business and which countries require an investment therein as a condition of doing business, is invested and maintained, either in bonds of the state, or in bonds of municipal, school, road, or levee district, or other political subdivisions of this state or in mortgages on property located in this state, or in real property in this state which shall be requisite for the convenient accommodation of the transaction of its own business, or in policy loans, or other loans to residents of this state, or to corporations organized under the laws of this state and domiciled in this state, or in stock of homestead building or loan associations organized under the laws of this state, to the extent such stock is guaranteed or insured by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation or other federal or state agency. 
(d)  All license taxes levied herein shall be due and payable on March 1 of each year and all unpaid license taxes shall become delinquent on June 1. The collection of delinquent accounts shall be enforced in accordance with R.S. 47:1601 and 47:1602. 
(Code 1966, § 17-02; Ord. No. 89-3434, §§ 1, 2, 5-11-89; Ord. No. 92-3608, § 1, 11-12-92) 
Editor's note— Ordinance No. 89-3434, §§ 1, 2, adopted May 11, 1989, was included as amending § 13-3. Section 5 of the ordinance provided that the ordinance shall become effective Jan. 1, 1990. 
State Law reference— Authorization, R.S. 22:1076.  
Sec. 13-4. - Collection of license taxes. 
The tax collector of the city is hereby directed to enforce the collection of the license taxes, yearly, as the law provides. 
(Code 1966, § 17-01)  
Sec. 13-5. - Payment of license taxes. 
The full amount of license taxes levied under this article shall be paid to the tax collector of the city on or before the first day of March each year, and the tax collector shall issue to the person making the payments a license certificate showing such payment. 
(Code 1966, § 17-03)  
Sec. 13-6. - Penalty. 
In case of any failure to make payment of license taxes as required by this chapter, ten (10) percent shall be added to the amount of the tax due unless satisfactory evidence is submitted to the tax collector to show that such failure was due to some unforeseen or unavoidable reason other than mere delay. If the delinquency be for more than thirty (30) days after the due date for the payment of license taxes hereunder, negligence will be presumed and ten (10) percent will be added without any discretion on the part of the tax collector, all of which shall be collected according to law. 
(Code 1966, § 17-04)  
Sec. 13-7. - Insufficient funds check-service charge. 
Any person, firm or corporation issuing insufficient funds check to the city in payment of monies due the city shall pay in addition to the check amount a service charge of fifteen dollars ($15.00) for each insufficient funds check. 
(Ord. No. 92-3574, § 1, 3-12-92)  
Sec. 13-8. - Occupational license required. 
No person, entity or other party shall engage in any activity defined in chapter 13 of the Code of Ordinances on or for which an occupational license tax may be levied without first obtaining an occupational license from the city. 
(Ord. No. 92-3602, § 1, 10-5-92; Ord. No. 05-4048, 2-10-05)  
Sec. 13-9. - Suspension, revocation, reapplication. 
(a)  The occupational license that is issued to any person may be suspended, revoked or terminated should the city find that the person so licensed has used the rights or privileges afforded by the occupational license to engage in or to otherwise aid, abet or facilitate others to engage in criminal or otherwise improper or illegal acts that are prohibited by local, municipal, state or federal laws and ordinances. When the occupational license of a person is revoked or otherwise terminated, the person shall, without the assent of the mayor and board of alderpersons providing otherwise, be ineligible to reapply for an occupational license for one (1) year thereafter. 
(b)  When a person's occupational license is considered for suspension or revocation as a result of a finding that the person using the privileges granted by the license engaged in or facilitated conduct, or procured, aided or abetted others in engaging in conduct, that is prohibited by the criminal code cited in the Code of Ordinances or other local, state or federal criminal laws, then the person shall, as a matter of due process, be entitled, before the revocation or suspension takes effect, to: 
(1)  Notice of the prohibited conduct that serves as the basis for suspension or revocation. 
(2)  Notice of the date and place when and where the prohibited conduct occurred. 
(3)  Notice of the recommended corrective action or penalty and the date of imposition. 
(4)  An opportunity to appear before the mayor for a due process conference, for the purpose of receiving or reviewing any charge of engaging of prohibited conduct, responding to any charge, refuting any charge, offering facts or information to refute the charge or to mitigate the degree of any penalty, or inquiring about any charge or the suspension and/or revocation process. 
(5)  An opportunity to be heard before the mayor and board of alderpersons, if requested. 
(c)  Suspension or revocation of an occupational license shall occur only upon an affirmative majority vote of the mayor and board of alderpersons. The actions of the city shall not be dependant on any charge or finding of criminal culpability or guilt, or a lack thereof, by a court or prosecuting authority. 
(d)  For a first offense, where it is determined by the city that a person engaged in prohibited conduct within the meaning of this section, the penalty may range from a warning up to revocation of a person's occupational license. For a second offense, the penalty may range from a suspension up to revocation of a person's occupational license. For a third offense or subsequent offense, the penalty may range from a suspension for a minimum period of six (6) months up to revocation of a person's occupational license. 
(Ord. No. 05-4048, 2-10-05)  
Sec. 13-10. - Permit for use of municipal property for business operations. 
No person or entity may enter upon, traverse, either above ground or below, or otherwise utilize any property, servitude, or other property right, owned, leased, possessed, or controlled by the city (herein referred to as "city property") for the conduct of business operations without first been issued a permit to enter city property for business operations as more fully set for the hereafter. 
(1)  Location of any system for business operations within city property without a valid permit from the city pursuant to this section presents a threat to the health, safety and welfare of the city's citizens and their property and is expressly forbidden. 
(2)  The city recognizes and reserves any and all rights available to it to regulate use of any city property. 
(3)  The granting of any city license, permit, or other requirement for doing business within the city shall not be construed as authorizing any such person or entity the right to utilize city property for the conduct of business operations. 
(4)  Any person or entity desiring to operate a system occupying city property ("applicant") shall make a written request to the city for a permit, which shall include the following information: 
a.  Name, address, telephone number, and contact person of the person or entity making the request; 
b.  Necessary corporate information, if applicable; 
c.  Name, address, email address, and home, office and cell telephone numbers of a person within authority to act on behalf of the applicant in case of emergency; 
d.  Description of the proposed activity; 
e.  Identification of the city property which applicant's system will occupy. Said identification shall include the following: 
i.  Map drawn to scale of the location of all applicant's system presently occupying city property; 
ii.  Inventory of all equipment, structures, and facilities comprising applicant's system occupying city property; and 
iii.  Description of all anticipated construction, major maintenance, and major installation activities which shall include the specific locations and the beginning and ending dates of all projects to be commenced during the next calendar year; and the tentative locations and beginning and ending dates for all projects contemplated for the two year period following the next calendar year. 
f.  Proof of comprehensive general liability insurance covering and affecting the applicant's business operations occupying city property. Applicant shall notify the city of cancellation of such policy(ies) at least thirty (30) days in advance of such cancellation; and 
g.  Name of all contractors acting or working on behalf of applicant within city property along with the name and home, office, and cell telephone numbers of a person with authority to act on behalf of the contractor in case of emergency. 
(5)  Upon provision of all of the information required by subsection (4), the city shall issue a permit allowing the applicant/permittee to enter city property to conduct business operations in accordance with the specific information provided to the city by the applicant/permittee. 
(6)  Standard provisions of each permit granted pursuant to this section shall include the following: 
a.  Conditions of occupancy. The system shall be located so as to cause minimum interference with the public uses of city property and with the rights and reasonable convenience of property owners who own property that adjoins city property. 
b.  Restoration of public ways. If, during the course of the permittee's construction, installation, or maintenance of the system, there occurs a disturbance of any city property by the permittee, the permittee shall replace and restore such city property to a condition reasonably comparable to the condition of the city property existing immediately prior to such disturbance. 
c.  Relocation at request of the city. If the city shall lawfully elect to vacate, relocate, abandon, alter, reconstruct or change any city property, the permittee, upon thirty (30) days written notice by the city via certified mail to the permittee, shall remove, re-lay and relocate its structure, equipment, and facilities at its own expense. Should the permittee refuse or fail to remove system within thirty (30) days after written notification, the city shall have the right to remove the component parts of the system and charge the permittee for the costs of removal. 
d.  Relocation at request of third party. The permittee shall, on the request of any person holding a lawful building moving permit, protect, support, raise, lower, temporarily disconnect, relocate in or remove from any city property, as necessary, any property of the permittee provided: (i) the expense of such is paid by said person benefiting from the relocation, including, if required by the permittee, making such payment in advance; and (ii) the permittee is given reasonable advance written notice to prepare for such changes. For purposes of this section, "reasonable advance written notice" shall be no less than thirty (30) days in the event of a temporary relocation, and no less than one hundred twenty (120) days for a permanent relocation. 
e.  Interference with use of right-of-way. When working within city property, permittee shall not unreasonably interfere with public uses of said city property and the safety, health, and convenience of the public in the public's use thereof for ordinary travel. 
(7)  No less than three (3) business days prior to commencement of construction, installation or maintenance activities within city property, the permittee shall notify the city of the specific locations and beginning and ending dates of said construction, installation, or maintenance project and shall provide current, accurate contact information for both the permittee and the contactor as outlined in subsection (4). Upon receipt of this notification, the city shall determine whether the proposed construction, installation, or maintenance activities shall pose an unreasonable inference with public uses. If the city determines the proposed activity presents no such unreasonable interference, it shall issue the permittee a notice to proceed. If the permittee receives no written notification from the city within twenty-four (24) hours of the proposed commencement of activities, the proposed activities may be deemed approved. This section shall not apply to emergency repair projects or utility service extension projects which the permittee could not have anticipated. 
(8)  The permittee shall keep all of the information required by subsection (4) current at all times by immediately providing the city written notice of changes. 
(9)  Any person or entity (1) whose system occupies city property for business operations without obtaining the permit required in this section; (2) who fails to provide the seventy-two-hour notice prior to commencement of construction, installation, or maintenance activities as required in subsection (6); or who fails to maintain current, accurate information required by subsection (4) concerning any system occupying city property may have any permit granted pursuant to this section revoked and may be denied future authorization for construction, installation, or maintenance activities for a period of two (2) years. 
(10)  Any violation of this section shall afford the city the full range of remedies available under any applicable law or regulation including the levying of fines. The election of one (1) or more remedies shall not be construed as a waiver of any other legal and/or equitable remedy including, but not limited to the city's right to seek injunctive relief, damage, and attorney's fees as the law might allow. 
(Ord. No. 08-4181, 9-11-08) 
Editor's note— Ordinance No. 08-4181, adopted September 11, 2008, did not specifically amend the Code. Therefore, such ordinance has been added as § 13-10 at the editor's discretion.  
Secs. 13-11—13-19. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - PEDDLERS AND SOLICITORS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Charter reference— Authority to regulate, § 5(28). 
Cross reference— Soliciting upon private residence, § 8-187. 
 
Sec. 13-20. - Definitions. 
As used in this article, the following terms shall have the respective meanings ascribed to them: 
Door-to-door vendor: Any person, and the agent or employee of any person, who engages in the temporary or transient business in the city of selling, or offering for sale, any goods or merchandise, or exhibiting the same for sale, or exhibiting the same for the purpose of taking orders for the sale thereof; and who for the purpose of carrying on such business or conducting such exhibits thereof does not hire, rent, lease, occupy or receive by donation, any room or space in any building, structure or other enclosure, or on any lot in the city in, through or from which any goods or merchandise may be sold, offered for sale, exhibited for sale or exhibited for the purpose of taking orders for the sale thereof. 
Temporary: Any such business transacted or conducted in the city for which definite arrangements have not been made for hire, rental or lease of premises for at least six (6) months, in or upon which such business is to be operated or conducted. 
Transient: Any such business of any such itinerant vendor and/or door-to-door vendor as may be operated or conducted by persons, or by their agents or employees, who reside away from the city, or who move stocks or goods or merchandise or samples thereof into the city with the purpose or intention of removing them or the unsold portion thereof away from the city before the expiration of six (6) months. 
(Code 1966, § 24-12; Ord. No. 3315, 5-13-86)  
Sec. 13-21. - Exemptions. 
This article, other than section 13-28, is not and shall not be applicable to the selling, or offering for sale, of any goods or merchandise, or exhibiting the same for sale, or exhibiting the same for the purpose of taking orders for the sale thereof: 
(1)  By a vendor of farm produce, or agricultural products in their natural state produced by such vendor; proof of such natural state and production by vendor shall be made to the city clerk; or 
(2)  If the proceeds thereof are applied to any charitable or philanthropic purposes; or 
(3)  At any crafts and arts fairs or festivals sponsored by a Louisiana nonprofit organization. 
(Code 1966, § 24-13; Ord. No. 3315, 5-13-86)  
Sec. 13-22. - Itinerant vendor's permit—application; conditions; bond. 
The permit for the itinerant vendor required by this article shall be issued upon the following conditions: 
(1)  Application: The itinerant vendor shall make application to the city clerk, at least ten (10) days prior to the date of contemplated sale or exhibit to be held in the city, which application shall be in the form of an affidavit stating: 
a.  The full name and address of the itinerant vendor; 
b.  The location of the itinerant vendor's principal office and place of business; 
c.  The location within the city from which the itinerant vendor shall sell, exhibit for sale, offer for sale, or exhibit for the purpose of taking orders for the sale of, such vendor's goods or merchandise; 
d.  The name and address of each assistant, associate or employee who shall work for and under the itinerant vendor; and 
e.  The names and address of its officers, if it is a corporation, and the partnership name and names and addresses of all partners, if such itinerant vendor is a firm. 
The itinerant vendor shall make a separate application to the city clerk for each location within the city from which such vendor will sell, exhibit for sale, offer for sale, or exhibit for the purpose of taking orders for the sale of, any goods or merchandise. 
(2)  Supporting information and bond: The application for a permit of an itinerant vendor must be accompanied by: 
a.  A statement showing the kind and character of the goods or merchandise to be sold, offered for sale, or exhibited; 
b.  A certified copy of the charter, if the itinerant vendor is a corporation incorporated under the laws of this state; 
c.  A certified copy of its permit to do business in this state if the itinerant vendor is a corporation incorporated under the laws of some other state; and 
d.  A bond in the sum of not less than five thousand dollars ($5,000.00), and it shall be executed by the itinerant vendor as principal, with one (1) or more good and sufficient sureties satisfactory to the city clerk, which bond shall be payable to the mayor of the city and the mayor's successors in office for the use and benefit of any persons entitled thereto, and conditioned that the principal and surety will pay all damages to person or persons caused by or arising from or growing out of the wrongful, fraudulent or illegal conduct of the itinerant vendor while conducting the same or exhibit in the city. The bond shall remain in full force and effect for the entire duration of the permit, as provided herein, and two (2) years thereafter. 
(Code 1966, § 24-17(a); Ord. No. 3315, 5-13-86)  
Sec. 13-23. - Same—scope; transferability; additional fee for employees. 
The permit of an itinerant vendor required by this article shall not be transferable from one (1) itinerant vendor to another, nor from one (1) location to another. It shall not give authority for more than one (1) person to sell, exhibit for sale, offer for sale or exhibit for the purpose of taking orders for the sale of, goods or merchandise as an itinerant vendor, but any itinerant vendor obtaining such permit shall be allowed two (2) assistants, associates or employees who shall work for such vendor, and in the event such person receiving such permit employs or has associated with such vendor more than two (2) assistants, associates or employees, then the permit fee hereinabove provided for shall be increased twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for each additional assistant, associate or employee. 
(Code 1966, § 24-18; Ord. No. 3315, 5-13-86)  
Sec. 13-24. - Same—During; display required. 
The permit of the itinerant vendor required by this article shall continue so long as such sale or exhibit is held at the permitted location for at least six (6) hours of each day and at least five (5) days of each calendar week, but in no event shall the permit continue for more than six (6) months from the date of its issuance. Such permit shall be prominently displayed in a conspicuous place on the permitted location where such sale or exhibit is being conducted, which conspicuous place shall be easily seen by the public in general, and it shall remain so displayed so long as any goods or merchandise are being sold or exhibited. 
(Code 1966, § 24-19; Ord. No. 3315, 5-13-86)  
Sec. 13-25. - Door-to-door vendor's permit—Application; conditions; bond; fee. 
The permit for the door-to-door vendor required by this article shall be issued upon the following conditions: 
(1)  Application: The door-to-door vendor shall make application to the city clerk at least ten (10) days prior to the date of contemplated sale or exhibit to be held in the city, which application shall be in the form of an affidavit stating: 
a.  The full name and addresses of the door-to-door vendor; 
b.  The location of the vendor's principal office and place of business; 
c.  The fact that the vendor shall not have a location within the city from which the door-to-door vendor shall sell, exhibit for sale, offer for sale, or exhibit for the purpose of taking orders for the sale of such vendor's goods or merchandise, but shall sell from door-to-door; 
d.  The name and address of each assistant, associate or employee who shall work for and under the door-to-door vendor; and 
e.  The names and address of its officers, if it is a corporation, and the partnership name and names and address of all partners, if such door-to-door vendor is a firm. 
(2)  Supporting information and bond: The application for a permit of a door-to-door vendor must be accompanied by: 
a.  A statement showing the kind and character of the goods or merchandise to be sold, offered for sale, or exhibited; 
b.  A certified copy of the charter, if the door-to-door vendor is a corporation incorporated under the laws of this state; 
c.  A certified copy of its permit to do business in this state if the door-to-door vendor is a corporation incorporated under the laws of some other state; and 
d.  A bond in the sum of not less than five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) and it shall be executed by the door-to-door vendor as principal, with one (1) or more good and sufficient sureties satisfactory to the director of administration, which bond shall be payable to the mayor of the city and the mayor's successors in office for the use and benefit of any persons entitled thereto, and conditioned that the principal and surety will pay all damages to person or persons caused by or arising from or growing out of the wrongful, fraudulent or illegal conduct of the door-to-door vendor while conducting the sale or exhibit in the city. The bond shall remain in full force and effect for the entire duration of the permit, as provided herein, and two (2) years thereafter. 
(3)  Issuance: The city clerk shall issue to any door-to-door vendor a permit authorizing such door-to-door vendor to sell, exhibit for sale, offer for sale, or exhibit for the purpose of taking orders for the sale, within the city limits of the city, of such vendor's goods or merchandise, only after the door-to-door vendor shall have fully complied with the provisions of this article and shall have paid the sum of one hundred dollars ($100.00) for the issuance of such permit. 
(Code 1966, §§ 24-13, 24-17(b); Ord. No. 3315, 5-13-86)  
Sec. 13-26. - Same—Transferability; additional fee. 
The permit of a door-to-door vendor required by this article shall not be transferable from one (1) door-to-door vendor to another. It shall not give authority for more than one (1) person to sell, exhibit for sale, offer for sale or exhibit for the purpose of taking orders for the sale of, goods or merchandise as a door-to-door vendor, but any door-to-door vendor obtaining such permit shall be allowed two (2) assistants, associates or employees who shall work for and under such vendor, and in the event such person receiving such permit employs or has associated with such person more than two (2) assistants, associates, or employees, then the permit fee hereinabove provided for shall be increased twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for each additional assistant, associate or employee. 
(Code 1966, § 24-18; Ord. No. 3315, 5-13-86)  
Sec. 13-27. - Same—Duration; exhibiting; making appointments. 
The permit of the door-to-door vendor required by this article shall continue for six (6) months from the date of its issuance. Such permit shall be carried on the person of the door-to-door vendor and exhibited to prospective purchasers. The door-to-door vendor shall, prior to calling at the home or place of business of prospective purchasers, make an appointment for such visit by telephone or by letter. 
(Code 1966, § 24-19; Ord. No. 3315, 5-13-86)  
Sec. 13-28. - Invitation required to go onto residential property. 
The practice of going in or upon private residential or other property in the city by solicitors, peddlers, hawkers, photographers, itinerant merchants, and transient vendors of merchandise not having been requested or invited to do so by the owner or occupant of such private property, for the purpose of soliciting orders or for the sale of goods, wares, or merchandise or the taking of pictures or the sale thereof or for the purpose of disposing of, peddling or hawking the same, is prohibited and declared to be a nuisance. 
(Code 1966, § 24-1; Ord. No. 3315, 5-13-86)  
Sec. 13-29. - Peddlers. 
There is hereby imposed and levied an annual license tax on all peddlers, hawkers, itinerant vendors and any person who displays samples, models, goods, wares or merchandise on a temporary basis in any hotel, motel, store, storehouse, house, vehicle, or any other place, provided that such place is outside of and not within the geographic area that forms the Bastrop Historic District, for the purpose of securing orders for the retail sale of goods, wares or the like kind or quality, either for immediate or future delivery shall obtain a license based on a fee of two hundred dollars ($200.00), provided than an itinerant vendor of agricultural products purchased directly from farmers or an itinerant vendor of seafood products who has either harvested the seafood himself or has purchased the seafood directly from commercial fishermen or shrimpers shall obtain a license based on a flat fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00). No peddler, hawker, itinerant vendor or other person may engage in the activities described in this section without first obtaining a license or permit as required by this section. 
Notwithstanding any provision of the Code of Ordinances that may provide to the contrary, no peddler, hawker, itinerant vendor or person may, by virtue of the license or permit issued to said party under the authority of this section, display samples, models, goods, wares or merchandise on a temporary basis in any hotel, motel, store, storehouse, house, vehicle, or any other place located within the geographic area that forms the Bastrop Historic District, for the purpose of securing orders for the retail sale of goods, wares or the like kind or quality, either for immediate or future delivery, except by special authorization granted by the mayor and board of alderpersons. 
All license taxes levied herein shall be due and payable on January 1 of each year and all unpaid license taxes shall become delinquent on March 1. The collection of delinquent accounts shall be enforced in accordance with state law, including state statutes R.S. 47:1601 and 47:1602. 
A cash or surety bond in the amount of one thousand five hundred dollars ($1,500.00) shall be deposited with the City Clerk for the City of Bastrop, Louisiana or with such other party or agency as the city may designate, to insure the proper payment and remittance of all applicable taxes (including sales and use taxes) that are owed by peddlers and all other persons identified in City Code of Ordinance section 13-29 ("hereafter collectively referred to as "peddler" or "peddlers") who are required to be licensed to do business within the City of Bastrop, Louisiana. The terms of the bond contract or agreement shall provide that the cash amount or bond posted shall indemnify the city and any other aggrieved party, including the Morehouse Parish Sales and Use Tax Commission, for the sum of one thousand five hundred dollars ($1,500.00), or any lesser sum upon the peddler's presentation of proof that a lesser sum is due, should the peddler fail to remit payment of all applicable taxes that are due. The bond shall be posted at the time that the peddler or such other party makes application for a license that is authorized to be issued under City Code of Ordinance section 13-29. 
(Ord. No. 87-3359, § 3, 6-9-87; Ord. No. 92-3603, §§ 1, 2, 10-5-92; Ord. No. 11-4206, 12-8-11; Ord. No. 12-4210, 6-14-12) 
State Law reference— Definition of peddler, R.S. 47:342(5); licensing authority, R.S. 47:359(C).  
Sec. 13-30. - Bucket brigades for solicitation of donations. 
(a)  Application to chief of police; training; etc. All persons, groups or organizations desiring to operate a "bucket brigade" for the purpose of soliciting donations for worthy causes shall apply to the chief of police or his designated representative sufficiently in advance of the date selected for the holding of the bucket brigade, attend any training session or conference conducted by the police department on the proper procedures therefor and conduct the bucket brigade only during the hours and on the streets approved by the chief of police or his designated representative. 
(b)  Identifying signs; posting; location of solicitors. All persons, groups or organizations conducting bucket brigades must use large easily read identifying signs stating the purpose for which donations are sought, the name of the donee, the name of the person, group or organization requesting donations and such signs must be posted on both sides of each street where solicitations will be made. Collections must be made from the curb sides of the street for the left lane of traffic and near the cross-walk area and centerline for the right lane of traffic. 
(c)  Age of solicitors; use of identifying vest; behavior. No one under the age of eleven (11) years shall be permitted to participate in a bucket brigade as a solicitor of funds, that for each two (2) children between the ages of eleven (11) and eighteen (18) years soliciting, one (1) adult solicitor must be present to supervise the children and no more than two (2) may solicit on any one (1) street at a time. All solicitors must wear an identifying vest or other distinctive clothing approved by the chief of police or his designated representative. All solicitors must be courteous at all times with such courtesy to include, but not be limited to, speech, gestures and other physical acts. 
(d)  Receipt, symbol or tag. Solicitors must give each donor an appropriate receipt, symbol or tag for the donation which can be displayed in the vehicle as a sign that a donation has been made. Receipt, symbol or tag must also be given to any noncontributory requesting the same and no additional request for donations can be made of persons displaying such receipt, symbol or tag. 
(e)  Number per year: No person, group or organization may be entitled to conduct more than two (2) bucket brigades for any one (1) purpose during a calendar year. 
(f)  Penalties for violation. Any person, firm or corporation violating any of the provisions of this section shall be fined not more than twenty-five dollars ($25.00) or imprisoned for not more than five (5) days or both. 
(Ord. No. 89-3643, §§ 1—6, 12-14-89) 
Editor's note— Ordinance No. 89-3463A, adopted Dec. 14, 1989, did not specifically amend this Code; hence, inclusion of §§ 1—6 as § 13-30 was at the discretion of the editor.  
Secs. 13-31—13-39. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - CHARITABLE GAMES OF CHANCE 
 
Sec. 13-40. - License—authority; exemptions. 
(a)  The city clerk or the clerk's designee is hereby authorized to license bona fide veterans, charitable, educational, religious, or fraternal organizations, civic and service clubs recognized as such under the laws of the state, and which organizations shall have qualified with the United States Internal Revenue Service for an exemption from federal income tax under section 501(c)(3), (4), (8), or (19) of the Internal Revenue Code, to hold and operate the specific kind of games of chance, commonly known as raffles, played by drawing for prizes or the allotment of prizes by chance, by the selling of shares or tickets or rights to participate in such games and by conducting the games accordingly; and the games of chance, commonly known as bingo or keno, played for prizes with cards bearing numbers or other designations, five (5) or more in one (1) line, the holder covering numbers, as objects, similarly numbered, are drawn from a receptacle and the game being won by the person who first covers a previously designated arrangement of numbers on such a card; by selling shares or tickets or rights to participate in such game or games and by conducting the games accordingly when the entire net proceeds of such games of change are to be devoted to educational, charitable, religious or public-spirited uses; and, when so licensed, to hold, operate and conduct such games of chance exclusively by its active members pursuant to this article, only on or in premises owned and occupied or leased by the licensee, unless a waiver is granted as hereinafter provided; and for such licensee to sell shares or tickets or rights to participate in such game or games of chance and under such conditions and regulations for the supervision and conduct thereof, as shall be promulgated by the city clerk or the clerk's designee, from time to time, and for any person to participate in and play such games of chance conducted under any such license. 
State Law reference— State law reference—Authority, R.S. 33:4861.1 et seq. 
(b)  A bona fide senior citizens' recreation club, upon application to the city clerk or the clerk's designee shall be exempt from the licensing and reporting procedure enumerated in this article. A "senior citizen recreation club" for the purposes of this article shall be defined as an organization, which is sanctioned by the local council on aging, composed of a group of persons sixty (60) years of age or older, whose only function is to provide amusement and diversion for its members. 
(Code 1966, § 26-01; Ord. No. 3338, 10-14-86)  
Sec. 13-40.1. - Electronic video bingo machines. 
(a)  Permitted at licensed locations. It shall be lawful for any bona fide nonprofit board, association, corporation, or other organization domiciled in this state and qualified with the United States Internal Revenue Service for an exemption from federal income tax under § 501(c)(3), (4), (5), (6), (7), (8), (10), or (19) of the Internal Revenue Code, or like organization authorized under the authority of R.S. 4:703, possessing a current, valid city and state bingo permit that authorizes the use of electronic video bingo machines, to use electronic video bingo machine or machines authorized pursuant to R.S. 4:701 et seq. at licensed locations; and the leasing or placement of such machines from state-approved distributors/suppliers. Any state-approved manufacturer or distributor of supplies or equipment for use in the conduct of any game of chance authorized under this section and any private contractor qualified to conduct games of chance as authorized under the provisions of R.S. 4:729 shall submit a permit application to the Office of the City Clerk for the City of Bastrop ("office of the city clerk"). "State-approved" denotes a person or entity specifically licensed or otherwise approved by the State of Louisiana in accordance with R.S. 4:701 et seq. 
(b)  Application for License. (1) Each state-approved manufacturer or distributor of supplies or equipment for use in the conduct of any game of chance authorized under this Ordinance and any private contractor qualified to conduct games of chance as authorized under the provisions of R.S. 4:729 within the City of Bastrop shall apply for and obtain, on an annual basis, an electronic video bingo distributor/manufacturer license from the City of Bastrop. (2) Every bona fide veteran's, charitable, educational, religious, or fraternal organization, civic, service club, and carnival organization ("EVBL") that desires to sponsor or conduct fund raising events using electronic video bingo machine or machines shall apply for and obtain an electronic video bingo organization permit from the City of Bastrop. Every distributor, manufacturer and EVBL seeking a license or permit shall file with the office of the city clerk written application therefore, in the form prescribed by the office of the city clerk, duly executed and verified, in which shall be stated the name and address of the applicant, the places or places where, the date or dates and the time or times when such electronic video bingo machine or machines are intended to be used by the applicant, or operated by the EVBL, under the license applied for. The majority of the organization's charity work shall be done within Morehouse Parish. During any calendar year, not more than one-third ( 1/3 ) of the EVBL permits issued by the city shall be granted to organizations whose domicile or principal place of business operations is outside of the corporate limits of the city, except that the mayor is hereby authorized to waive this limitation for good cause. 
(c)  Term of license or permit. Licenses or permits issued by the city to a distributor, manufacturer and EVBL shall be effective each year from the period of January first through December 31st of the same year. Fees for a partial calendar year shall not be pro-rated. 
(d)  License processing fee. An annual nonrefundable fee of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) shall be paid to the city to defray the costs of reviewing and processing an application, and for licensing a distributor, manufacturer or operator. EVBLs that seek a charitable organization permit shall pay an annual nonrefundable fee of ten dollars ($10.00). This licensing fee shall be in addition to occupational license fees that may be owed. 
(e)  Machine permit fee. An annual permit fee of ten dollars ($10.00) for each machine to be permitted on the licensee's premises shall be paid to the city and be included with the application or renewal application. 
(f)  Quarterly statement. Not later than twenty days (20) days after January 1, April 1, July 1, and October 1, of each year, each licensee shall furnish the licensing body a sworn (notarized) and verified statement indicating total payment, cash or coins in, credit played, credits won and credits paid. 
(g)  Maximum number of machines permitted. No one site used by a licensee or permittee under the Ordinance shall have more than thirty-five (35) electronic video bingo machines in each licensed location, subject to the exception provided for below in section (j). 
(h)  Louisiana statutory provisions. Where any provisions hereof conflict with the provisions of R.S. 4:701 et seq., the applicable provisions of such state law and applicable provisions contained in the Louisiana Administrative Code promulgated pursuant thereto, shall govern. Each EVBL shall meet all requirements of state law regarding the operation of electronic video bingo games and use of electronic video bingo machines. 
(i)  Licensed locations. The operation of electronic video bingo machines as authorized by this Ordinance shall not be allowed in any property zoned residential or in any location prohibited by city zoning ordinances. Unless otherwise specified by the mayor and board of alderpersons, it shall be unlawful for the operation of any licensed electronic video bingo machines at any location other than at locations bearing municipal addresses located on (and with ingress and egress by public right-of-way to and from) U.S. Highways 165 and 425, and Louisiana Highway 139. In addition, and unless otherwise specified by the mayor and board of alderpersons by adoption of a city ordinance, it shall be unlawful for the operation of any licensed electronic video bingo machines at any location that has less than seventy-five (75) on-site parking spaces for motor vehicles, which must lie completely outside of any public roads or rights-of-way, provided further that said parking is immediately adjacent to an enclosed building or structure that will house the electronic video bingo machines and is not separated by any public roadway. 
(j)  Number of licensed locations. It shall be unlawful a single licensee to have more than two (2) sites located in the City of Bastrop without the specific authorization of the mayor and board of alderpersons. However, two halls under the same authority or ownership that are within the same structure, or that are in not more than two (2) separate structures that are within two hundred (200) feet of each other, can be considered one site. Nevertheless, and subject to the exception provided for below, at no time shall there be more than three (3) licensed locations in the City of Bastrop. For a two-year period commencing on and from the date in 2007 that electronic video bingo machines become operational, only one applicant will be approved for the operation of electronic video bingo machines within the city, and said applicant shall be granted the exclusive right to operate a minimum of thirty-five (35) machines for up to two years. The city may authorize the operation of additional machines during this period. Thereafter, the city may authorize the licensing of additional operators for additional locations within the city in a manner consistent with this section. The mayor is authorized to execute such contracts and to perform such other required acts that are needed to confect and make effective the exclusive agreement referenced herein and any subsequent agreements with licensees. 
(k)  Sessions. A session represents electronic video bingo games played within a time limit not to exceed six (6) hours within a minimum of twelve (12) hours between sessions. Sessions are limited to not more than one (1) session per day per EVBL. No EVBL shall be permitted to operate electronic video bingo games for more than fifteen (15) sessions in any calendar month. Notwithstanding any provision contained in any ordinance to the contrary, all types of bingo sessions may be allowed to the extent and at the times allowed for electronic video bingo. 
(l)  Net proceeds. For purposes of this Ordinance, the term "net win" shall mean the sum obtained by subtracting total coins for funds paid in or earned minus the total amount paid out on ticket vouchers tendered for cash money. Not less than twenty (20) percent of the net win from each electronic video bingo machine shall be paid as an assessment or tax owed to the city; however, during the first two years that electronic video bingo operates in the city pursuant to the exclusive agreement referenced in section (j), the city shall accept an assessment of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) per month, in lieu of twenty (20) percent of the net win, during the first 12 months of the exclusive agreement. The tax or assessment owed to the city from the net win shall be owed and become due on the first day of the month that follows the previous month of operations. Taxes or assessments that are not paid to the city by the fifth day of the month in which they become due shall incur a penalty of two (2) percent per month until paid. 
(m)  General. Except as specifically provided with respect to electronic video bingo, all other requirements and penalties relating to bingo, keno and raffles shall apply to the operation of electronic video bingo machines. To the extent that any this section is in conflict with any other section(s) of this chapter, the provisions of the section shall control. 
(Ord. No. 07-4117, 1-11-07; Ord. No. 07-4118, 1-22-07; Ord. No. 07-4131, 6-14-07)  
Sec. 13-41. - Same—application; designating responsible person. 
(a)  Each applicant for such a license shall file with the city clerk or the clerk's designee a written application therefor in the form prescribed herein, duly executed and verified, in which shall be stated: 
(1)  The name and address of the applicant together with sufficient facts relating to its incorporation and/or organization to enable a determination of whether or not it is a bona fide organization or corporation subject to the provisions of this article; 
(2)  The names and addresses of its officers; 
(3)  The specific kind of games of chance intended to be held, operated and conducted by the applicant, and the places where, the dates and the times when, such games of chance are intended to be conducted, by the applicant, under the license applied for; 
(4)  The items of expense intended to be incurred or paid in connection with the holding, operating and conducting of such games of chance and the names and addresses of the persons to whom, and the purposes for which, they are to be paid; 
(5)  The specific purposes of which the entire net proceeds of such games of chance are to be devoted and in what manner; 
(6)  That no commission, salary, compensation, reward or recompense will be paid to any person for holding, operating and conducting or assisting in the holding, operating and conducting of, such games of chance; 
(7)  A description of all prizes to be offered and given in all such games of chance to be held, operated and conducted under such license; 
(8)  Such other information as shall be prescribed by the regulations promulgated by the city clerk from time to time. 
(b)  In each application there shall be designated one (1) or more active members of the applicant under whom the games of chance described in the application are to be held, operated and conducted and to the application shall be appended a statement executed by the applicant and by the members so designated, that they will be responsible for the holding, operating and conducting of such games of chance in accordance with the terms of the license and the provisions of regulations governing the holding, operating and conducting of such games of chance and of this article, if such license is granted. 
(Code 1966, § 26-02; Ord. No. 3338, 10-14-86)  
Sec. 13-42. - Same—Investigation of qualifications of applicant; issuance. 
(a)  The city clerk or the clerk's designee shall make an investigation of the qualifications of each applicant and the merits of the application, with due expedition after the filing of the application, and shall make the following determinations: 
(1)  That the applicant is duly qualified to hold, operate and conduct games of chance under the provisions of this article and the rules and regulations governing the holding, operating and conducting thereof in the municipality. 
(2)  That the members of the organization designated in the application to hold, operate, or conduct or assist in holding, operating, or conducting the games of chance for which the license application is made are bona fide active members of the applicant and are persons of good moral character who have never been convicted of certain related offenses as established by the division of charitable gaming control of the office of state police within the state department of public safety and corrections. 
(3)  That such games of chance are to be held, operated and conducted in accordance with the provisions of this article and in accordance with the rules and regulations governing the holding, operating, and conducting thereof and that the proceeds thereof are to be disposed of as provided by this article. 
(b)  If the governing body is satisfied that no commission, salary, compensation, reward, or recompense whatever will be paid or given to any person holding, operating or conducting or assisting in the holding, operating or conducting of any such game of chance, it shall issue a license to the applicant for the holding; operating and conducting of the specific kind of games of chance applied for accordingly. 
(c)  No license for holding, operating, or conducting of any game or games of chance shall be issued under this article to be effective for a period of more than one (1) calendar year. 
(Code 1966, § 26-03; Ord. No. 3338, 10-14-86)  
Sec. 13-43. - Same—Special. 
(a)  Notwithstanding any other provision of this article to the contrary, the governing body may provide by ordinance for the issuance of a special license for the conduct of not more than two (2) bingo sessions annually at which the total amount of prizes which may be awarded on any one (1) calendar day under such a license shall not exceed twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) in cash or other thing or things of value. Except as otherwise provided in this section, all other provisions of this article shall apply to the issuance of such special licenses. 
(b)  The governing body shall not issue a special license or a regular license to any organization as provided herein unless that organization has first obtained a special charitable gaming license from the division of charitable gaming control of the office of state police within the state department of public safety and corrections, as further provided in R.S. 40:1485.5. 
(Code 1966, § 26-04; Ord. No. 3338, 10-14-86)  
Sec. 13-44. - Same—Refusal; amending; suspension and revocation. 
(a)  In the event the city clerk or the clerk's designee refuses to issue a license to an applicant, the applicant shall have the right to a hearing to be held before the governing body at a regular or special meeting. In the event the applicant desires such a hearing, the applicant shall notify the city clerk in writing by registered or certified mail, return receipt requested, of such desire. At least fifteen (15) days prior to the meeting of the governing body at which the applicant shall be entitled to be heard upon the qualifications of the applicant and the merits of the application, the city clerk shall notify the applicant in writing, mailed to the applicant at the address shown on the application by registered or certified mail, return receipt requested, of the date and time of the meeting of the governing body. 
(b)  Any license issued under this article may be amended, upon application made to the city clerk or the clerk's designee, if the subject matter of the proposed amendment could lawfully and properly have been included in the original license. 
(c)  The city clerk or the clerk's designee shall have the power and authority to suspend any license issued by the city and/or revoke the same. In the event the city clerk or designee suspends and/or revokes any license so issued, the licensee shall have the right to a hearing to be held before the governing body at a regular or special meeting. In the event the licensee desires such a hearing, the licensee shall notify the city clerk in writing by registered or certified mail, return receipt requested, of such desire. At least fifteen (15) days prior to the meeting of the governing body at which the licensee shall be entitled to be heard upon the reasons for the suspension and/or revocation, the city clerk shall notify the licensee in writing, mailed to the licensee at the address shown on the license by registered or certified mail, return receipt requested, of the date and time of the meeting of the governing body. 
(Code 1966, §§ 26-05, 26-07; Ord. No. 3338, 10-14-86)  
Sec. 13-45. - Same—Form; display; fees; duration. 
(a)  Each license shall be in such form as shall be prescribed in the regulations promulgated by the city clerk or the clerk's designee and shall contain: 
(1)  A description of the kinds of games of chance authorized to be held, operated and conducted thereunder; 
(2)  A statement of the name and address of the licensee; 
(3)  A statement of the names and addresses of the members of the applicant under whom such games of chance will be held, operated and conducted; 
(4)  A statement of the number of times, or the hours during which, such games of chance are authorized to be conducted and the places where and the dates and the times when such games of chance are to be conducted; 
(5)  A statement of the specific purposes to which the entire net proceeds of such games of chance are to be devoted; 
(6)  Any other information which may be required by the regulations shall be contained therein. 
(b)  Each license issued for the conduct of any game of chance shall be conspicuously displayed at the place where the game is to be conducted thereunder at all times during the conduct thereof. 
(c)  If the licensee requests a license for only one (1) game of chance authorized to be held, operated and conducted hereunder, the licensee shall pay to the city the sum of fifty dollars ($50.00) for the issuance of such license, which license fee shall be paid prior to the issuance of such license. If the licensee requests license for more than one (1) game of chance authorized to be held, operated and conducted hereunder in any calendar year, the licensee shall pay to the city the sum of one hundred dollars ($100.00) for the issuance of such license, which license fee shall be paid prior to the issuance of such license. All licenses issued pursuant to this subsection shall be for the fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00), regardless of the period of time remaining in the current calendar year for which the same are issued. 
(d)  The license shall be effective for the calendar year for which it is issued. 
(Code 1966, §§ 26-06, 26-13; Ord. No. 3338, 10-14-86)  
Sec. 13-46. - Conduct and supervision over games; right of entry of officers. 
The governing body shall have and exercise control and supervision over all games of chance held, operated and conducted under such license, to the end that the same are fairly held, operated and conducted in accordance with the provisions of such license, the regulations promulgated by the city clerk or designee and the provisions of this article and R.S. 33:4861.1 et seq., governing the holding, operating and conducting of the same. 
(Code 1966, § 26-07; Ord. No. 3338, 10-14-86)  
Sec. 13-47. - Number of games per month; number of prizes per game. 
(a)  No licensee shall hold, operate or conduct any game or games of chance under any license issued under this article more often than on twelve (12) days in one (1) calendar month. 
(b)  The total amount of prizes which may be awarded on any one (1) session by a licensee shall not exceed four thousand five hundred dollars ($4,500.00) in cash or other things of value, except as specifically provided in R.S. 33:4861.7, R.S. 33:4861.17 and R.S. 33:4861.18. 
(Code 1966, § 26-08; Ord. No. 3338, 10-14-86)  
Sec. 13-48. - Restrictions on conducting of games. 
(a)  No person shall hold, operate and conduct or assist in holding, operating and conducting of any game of chance under any license issued under this article, except after full compliance with the provisions of R.S. 33:4861.1 et seq., and except an active member of the organization to which the license is issued. 
(b)  No such game of chance shall be conducted with any equipment except such as shall be owned absolutely or used without payment of any compensation thereof by the licensee. 
(c)  No item of expense shall be incurred or paid in connection with the holding, operating and conducting of any game of chance held, operated and conducted pursuant to any license issued under this article, except such as bona fide items of reasonable amounts of goods, wares and merchandise furnished or services rendered, which are reasonably necessary to be purchased or furnished for the holding, operating and conducting thereof, under any circumstances whatever. 
(d)  No commission, salary, compensation, reward or recompense whatever shall be paid or given, directly or indirectly, to any person holding, operating and conducting, or assisting in the holding, operating and conducting of any game or games of chance so held, operated and conducted. 
(e)  Any such game or games shall be held, operated and conducted only on or in premises owned and occupied or leased by the licensee hereunder, unless a waiver is granted by the city clerk or the clerk's designee upon written request by the licensee. 
(Code 1966, § 26-09; Ord. No. 3338, 10-14-86)  
Sec. 13-49. - Statement of receipts; expenditures; books and records required. 
(a)  No later than ten (10) days after the end of the month in which the game of chance was held, operated and conducted, the organization or association which held, operated and conducted the game and its member or members who were in charge thereof, shall furnish to the city clerk or his designee, the following: 
(1)  A verified statement showing the amount of the gross receipts derived from each such game of chance, which shall include receipts from the sale of shares, tickets or rights in any manner connected with participation in such game or the right to participate therein; 
(2)  Each item of expense incurred, or paid, and each item of expenditure made or to be made; 
(3)  Name and address of each person to whom each such item has been, or is to be paid, with a detailed description of the merchandise purchased or the services rendered therefor; 
(4)  The net profit derived from each such game of chance, and the uses to which such net profit has been or is to be applied; and 
(5)  A list of prizes offered or given, with the respective values thereof. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of each licensee to maintain and keep such books and records as may be necessary to substantiate the particulars of each such report. 
(Code 1966, § 26-10; Ord. No. 3338, 10-14-86)  
Sec. 13-50. - Examination of books, records and personnel. 
The city clerk or the clerk's designee shall have the power to examine or to cause to be examined the books and records of any organization or association to which such license is issued so far as they may relate to any transaction connected with the holding and conducting of any game of chance thereunder and to examine any manager, officer, director, agent, member or employee thereof under oath in relation to the conduct of any such game of chance under any such license; but any information so received shall not be disclosed except so far as may be necessary for the purpose of carrying out the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1966, § 26-11; Ord. No. 3338, 10-14-86)  
Sec. 13-51. - Violations. 
(a)  Any person who shall make any false statement in any application for a license under this article, or shall fail to keep such books and records as shall fully and truly record all transactions connected with the holding, operating and conducting of games of chance under any such license or shall falsify or make any false entry in any books or records so far as they relate to any transaction connected with the holding, operating and conducting of any game of chance under any such license or shall violate any of the provisions of this article or of any term of such license, shall be a disorderly person and if convicted as such, shall, in addition to suffering any other penalties which may be imposed, forfeit any license issued to it under this article and shall be ineligible to apply for a license under this article for one (1) year thereafter. 
(b)  All activities conducted requiring such license by the proposed licensee who has not obtained such license shall subject the conductors of such activity to the criminal penalties to which the conductors of unlicensed games of chance, as described in this article, are subject. 
(Code 1966, §§ 26-06, 26-12; Ord. No. 3338, 10-14-86)  
Secs. 13-52—13-59. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - SALES AND USE TAXES 
 
Sec. 13-60. - Ordinances incorporated by reference. 
Ordinance number 3261, dated May 14, 1985, and ordinance number 88-3402, dated July 19, 1988, levying sales and use taxes are hereby incorporated into and made a part of this Code by reference, as fully as if set out at length herein.  
Secs. 13-61—13-69. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - GOING-OUT-OF-BUSINESS, FIRE, BANKRUPTCY OR FIDUCIARY SALES 
 
Sec. 13-70. - Definitions. 
As used in this article, the following terms shall have the respective meanings ascribed to them [in this section]: 
Going-out-of-business, fire, bankruptcy, or fiduciary sale includes an insurance, mortgage, insolvent, assignees, executors, administrators, receivers, trustees, removal or closing-out sale, a sale of damaged goods, or a sale in which a merchant advertises that he is disposing of all goods, as a means of ceasing to do business. 
Goods includes goods, wares and merchandise. 
(Ord. No. 89-3454, § 1, 9-14-89)  
Sec. 13-71. - Exemptions. 
The provisions of this part shall not apply to sheriffs, constables, or public or court officers, or to persons acting under the license, direction or authority of any court, state or federal, selling goods in the course of their official duties. 
(Ord. No. 89-3454, § 2, 9-14-89)  
Sec. 13-72. - License—Required. 
Every person who advertises, represents or holds out that any sale of goods is a going-out-of-business, fire, bankruptcy or fiduciary sale shall first obtain a license to conduct the sale from the mayor of the city. 
(Ord. No. 89-3454, § 3, 9-14-89)  
Sec. 13-73. - Same—Application; contents. 
(a)  Every person who desires a license under the provisions of this article shall make an application to the mayor in writing and under oath, showing all the facts in regard to the going-out-of-business, insurance, bankruptcy, mortgage, insolvency, assignment, administration, receivership, trusteeship or removal by reason of which the sale is to be conducted, or in regard to the closing-out of his stock of goods, or any particular line or part with the statement as to the reason for the closing-out, or in regard to the damage to the goods, and in regard to the sale which he proposes to conduct, the place and manner of conducting it, including an inventory of the goods to be sold, a statement, as far as possible, of the names of the persons from whom the goods were obtained, the date of delivery of the goods to the person applying for the license, the place from which the goods were last taken, and all details necessary to identify fully the goods to be sold. The application shall also specify whether the applicant proposes to advertise or conduct the sale as a going-out-of-business, fire, bankruptcy or fiduciary sale with a statement of the fiduciary relationship. 
(b)  The application shall specify the proposed period of time over which the sale is to continue, which period shall not exceed three (3) months. If it appears, upon sworn application to the mayor, at any time during during the three-month period, that all of the goods described in the inventory in the original application have not been sold, and if the application is accompanied by an inventory of what remains, a supplemental license, granting authority to continue the sale for a further period of three (3) months shall be issued by the mayor upon the same terms and conditions as the original license. 
(Ord. No. 89-3454, § 4, 9-14-89)  
Sec. 13-74. - Same—Issuance. 
If the mayor is satisfied from the application required by section 13-73 that the proposed sale is of the character which the applicant desires to conduct and advertise, he shall issue a license upon the payment of the fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00), to the person applying, authorizing him to advertise and conduct a sale of the particular kind mentioned in the application, according to the requirements of this article. 
(Ord. No. 89-3454, § 5, 9-14-89)  
Sec. 13-75. - Same—Record of application; abstract. 
The mayor to whom application is made, as provided for in section 13-73, shall endorse upon the application the date of its filing, preserve it in a record of his office, make an abstract of the facts set forth in the application in a book, properly indexed and kept for this purpose, which abstract shall contain the name of the person asking for a license, the nature of the proposed sale, the place where the sale is to be conducted, its duration, the inventory value of the goods to be sold, and a general statement as to where the goods came from, and make in the book a notation as to the issuance or refusal of the license applied for, together with the date of issuance or refusal and endorse on the application the date that the license, as applied for, is granted or refused. The application and abstract should be prima facie evidence of all statements contained therein. 
(Ord. No. 89-3454, § 6, 9-14-89)  
Sec. 13-76. - Same—Removal of goods; validity. 
The license required by section 13-72 shall be valid only for a sale of the goods inventoried and described in the application for a license in the manner and at the time and place mentioned and set forth in the application. Any removal of the goods so inventoried and described in the application on the place of sale mentioned in the application shall cause the goods to lose their identity as an insurance, bankrupt, mortgage, insolvent's, assignees', executors', administrators', receivers' or trustees' stock of goods or a damaged stock of goods, and thereafter no license shall be issued for the conducting of a sale of any goods so removed from the place set forth and described in the application, under the provisions of this article and any other place. 
(Ord. No. 89-3454, § 7, 9-14-89)  
Sec. 13-77. - Additional goods—purchase for resale prohibited. 
No person intending to conduct a going-out-of-business, fire, bankruptcy or fiduciary sale under the license required by section 13-72 shall order any goods for the purpose of selling and disposing of the same at the sale, and any unusual purchase and additions to the stock of goods within sixty (60) days prior to the filing of the application for license to conduct the sale mentioned in section 13-73 shall be presumptive evidence that the purchases and additions of the stock were made in contemplation of the sale and for the purpose of selling the purchases and additions at the sale. 
(Ord. No. 89-3454, § 8, 9-14-89)  
Sec. 13-78. - Same—Not to be added during sale. 
(a)  No person carrying on or conducting a going-out-of-business, fire, bankruptcy or fiduciary sale under the license required by section 13-72 shall, during the continuance of the sale, add any goods to the stock of goods described and inventoried in his original application, and no goods shall be sold at or during the sale, except the goods described and inventoried in such original application. 
(b)  Each and every and every addition of goods to the stock of goods described and inventoried in the application, and each sale of the goods inventoried and described in the application, shall constitute a separate offense under this article. 
(Ord. No. 89-3454, § 9, 9-14-89)  
Sec. 13-79. - False advertising; penalty for violation of section. 
(a)  No person shall advertise, represent or hold out any sale of goods to be a going-out-of-business, fire, bankruptcy or fiduciary sale without having complied with the provisions of this article. 
(b)  Whoever violates this section shall be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00), nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00), or imprisoned for not more than six (6) months, or both. 
(Ord. No. 89-3454, § 10, 9-14-89)  
Sec. 13-80. - Violations of article; penalty. 
(a)  No person shall hold, or carry on any sale of goods as a going-out-of-business, fire, bankruptcy or fiduciary sale contrary to the provisions of this article. 
(b)  Whoever violates any of the provisions of this article, except as provided in section 13-79, shall be fined not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00), nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00), or imprisoned for not more than six months, or both. 
(Ord. No. 89-3454, § 11, 9-14-89)  
Secs. 13-81—13-99. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VI. - DEALERS IN USED GOODS[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference— Junk, § 10-40 et seq. 
 
DIVISION 1. - PAWNBROKERS 
 
Sec. 13-100. - Pawnbroker defined. 
"Pawnbroker" means a person, partnership or corporation, who lends money on deposit or pledge, or who takes other things as security for the money advanced, or who purchases property for the purpose of selling it back at a stipulated price, or who makes a public display at his place of business of the sign generally used by pawnbrokers to denote their business, namely, three (3) gilt or yellow balls, or who publicly exhibits a sign that money is to be loaned on personal property or deposit. 
(Ord. No. 90-3481, § 1, 4-12-90)  
Sec. 13-101. - License required. 
(a)  No person shall do business as a pawnbroker without having first obtained the license required by La.R.S. 37:1752, La.R.S. 47:350, and section 13-1 of the Code of Ordinances of the city. Any person desiring a license as pawnbroker shall make application, in writing, stating the full name(s) and residence(s) of the applicant(s). If the applicant is a partnership, or if a corporation, the name and residence of each of its officers and the location at which the business will be conducted, will be included on the application. 
(b)  Upon the payment of the license fee and the filing of the bond hereafter provided for, the applicant shall be licensed to carry on, conduct or engage in the business of pawnbroker at the place designated in the license. 
(Ord. No. 90-3481, § 1, 4-12-90)  
Sec. 13-102. - Location of business. 
(a)  If, after issuance and delivery of a license under the provisions of this article, any change is made in the location of the place of business designated therein, the business shall not be conducted at the location or under such license until the official issuing the license notes the change on the license and the chief of police, Bastrop police department, and the sheriff of Morehouse Parish are notified in writing of the change. 
(b)  If the business is being carried on, conducted or engaged in more than one (1) location, then each location must have a separate license. 
(Ord. No. 90-3481, § 1, 4-12-90)  
Sec. 13-103. - Bond. 
Every applicant for a license under the provisions of this article shall submit with the application a bond in favor of the city in the amount of five hundred dollars ($500.00), with security, conditioned for the due observance of all provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 90-3481, § 1, 4-12-90)  
Sec. 13-104. - Book to be kept; entries required. 
(a)  Every pawnbroker shall keep a book which shall be a bound volume, in which shall be fairly written in ink at the time of each transaction, an accurate description in the English language of the person making the loan or selling any goods, as well as an accurate description of the goods, article or item pawned, pledged or sold, the amount of money loaned thereon, and the time of pledging the same. When a watch is pawned, the number, name of maker, all letters or marks thereon must also be entered in the book; and whenever any articles manufactured from gold or silver are pawned, all letters or marks thereon must also be entered in the same book. 
(b)  The name, address, sex, race, height, weight, Social Security number and driver's license number of the person or persons making the loan, pledging, pawning, selling or delivering said merchandise to the pawnbroker shall be obtained and included with each ledger entry. 
(c)  Records of each transaction shall be preserved for a period of at least three (3) years. No entry made in such book shall be erased, obliterated, defaced or removed. 
(Ord. No. 90-3481, § 1, 4-12-90)  
Sec. 13-105. - Photographic and other records; exceptions. 
In addition to the information required in section 13-104, every pawnbroker shall be required to obtain a photograph of a person selling or delivering merchandise to the dealer. The quality of such photograph shall be sufficient to readily identify the person depicted. In lieu of the photograph of the person selling or delivering the merchandise, pawnbrokers may obtain a thumbprint of such person, the quality of which thumbprint shall be sufficient to readily identify the person. Each photograph or thumbprint shall be cross-referenced with the ledger entry required by section 13-104, and shall be preserved for a period of at least three (3) years. 
(Ord. No. 90-3481, § 1, 4-12-90)  
Sec. 13-106. - Book to be open for inspection. 
The book containing the records of loans, pledges, purchases and deliveries required in section 13-104 and the various articles pledged and referred to therein shall at all times be opened to the inspection of law enforcement officers of the Louisiana state police, the Bastrop police department and the Morehouse Parish sheriff's department. 
(Ord. No. 90-3481, § 1, 4-12-90)  
Sec. 13-107. - Copy of book entries to be furnished daily. 
Every person licensed under the provisions of this article shall make and deliver to the Bastrop police department and the Morehouse Parish sheriff's department, every day before the hour of 12:00 noon, a legible and correct copy of the entries made in the book required by section 13-104, during the previous day. In lieu of the copies of entries made in the book required above, pawnbrokers may furnish to the Bastrop police department and the Morehouse Parish sheriff's department a copy of each of the tickets required by section 13-119 below. This exception is allowable only if the tickets or memoranda are sequentially numbered and a copy of each and every ticket and/or memoranda is furnished. 
(Ord. No. 90-3481, § 1, 4-12-90)  
Sec. 13-108. - Sale of property, time for; record. 
(a)  No pawnbroker shall sell any jewelry pledged to him as collateral security for loans made before a lapse of twelve (12) months from the time of the loan; neither shall he sell other property other than jewelry pledged to him for a loan before the lapse of three (3) months. 
(b)  All sales of property by a pawnbroker, whether acquired through forfeiture or purchase, shall be recorded in the same manner as required in section 13-104. 
(Ord. No. 90-3481, § 1, 4-12-90)  
Sec. 13-109. - Hours of pawnbrokers. 
A pawnbroker shall neither open his place of business before the hour of 7:30 a.m. nor keep it open after the hour of 7:00 p.m., except Saturdays and the month of December, during which times the hour of 7:00 p.m. shall be extended to 10:00 p.m. 
(Ord. No. 90-3481, § 1, 4-12-90)  
Sec. 13-110. - Minors; taking property in payment or pledge. 
No pawnbroker shall take or receive in payment or pledge for money loaned, any property, bonds, notes, securities, articles, or other things of value from any minor. Lack of knowledge of age shall not be defense to a violation of this section. 
(Ord. No. 90-3481, § 1, 4-12-90)  
Sec. 13-111. - Violations by pawnbrokers; penalty. 
Any pawnbroker who shall violate, neglect or refuse to comply with any provisions of this article shall be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00), or imprisoned for not less than ten (10) days or more than thirty (30) days, or both, for the first offense. For the second and subsequent offenses, the pawnbroker shall be fined five hundred dollars ($500.00), or imprisoned for not less than thirty (30) days nor more than sixty (60) days, or both. If convicted three (3) times, his license shall be revoked and he shall thereafter not be permitted to engage in the business of pawnbroker in the city. 
(Ord. No. 90-3481, § 1, 4-12-90)  
Sec. 13-112. - Failure to comply; penalty.
