(Code 1966, § 23-100)  
Sec. 19-14. - Commercial vehicle route. 
No person shall operate or move or cause to be operated or moved upon the following streets or parts of streets of the city any commercial vehicle transporting people for hire, or any truck, private or commercial, having a load limit capacity greater than one (1) ton without the written permission of the chief of police: 
(1)  West Hickory Avenue from its intersection with West Madison Avenue to its intersection with the West right-of-way line of South Vine Street. 
(2)  Juanita Street from its intersection with Collinston Road to its intersection with Naff Street. 
(Code 1966, § 23-49; Ord. No. 2850, § 1, 6-14-77)  
Sec. 19-15. - Driving vehicles on sidewalks. 
The driver of a vehicle shall not drive within any sidewalk area except at a permanent or temporary driveway. 
(Code 1966, § 23-107)  
Sec. 19-16. - Riding bicycles on sidewalks. 
No person shall ride a bicycle upon a sidewalk within the city. 
(Code 1966, § 23-115)  
Sec. 19-17. - Jaywalking. 
It shall be unlawful for any person or pedestrian to cross the street diagonally or "jay-walk" at any street intersection. 
(Code 1966, § 23-121)  
Sec. 19-18. - Railroads—Blocking traffic. 
No directing officer or operator of any railroad train shall direct the operation of or operate the same in such a manner as to prevent the use of any street for purposes of travel for a period of time longer than five (5) minutes, except that this provision shall not apply to trains in motion other than those engaged in switching. 
(Code 1966, § 23-125) 
Charter reference— Authority, § 5(16)  
Sec. 19-19. - Same—Flagging traffic in backing across crossings. 
No directing officer or operator of any railroad train shall direct the operation of or operate the same in backing it or any part of it across any street crossing where automatic warning signals are not provided and working properly without providing for the warning of traffic by placing a flagman at the crossing to warn approaching traffic on the street. 
(Code 1966, § 23-126)  
Sec. 19-20. - Skateboards prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to use, operate or ride any skateboards upon a sidewalk or public tennis court in the city. 
(Ord. No. 90-3490, § 1, 6-14-90)  
Sec. 19-20.1. - Inspection sticker required. 
(a)  No person shall drive a vehicle upon the streets of this city, or permit or allow any vehicle owned or under his control to be driven on the streets, unless and until such vehicle bears a current inspection tag showing it to have been inspected and approved as required by the provisions of R.S. 32:1301—32:1310, if such vehicle is required to be so inspected. 
(b)  Whoever violates the provisions of subsection (a) above shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, shall be punished by a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisoned in jail for not more than six (6) months, or both, in the discretion of the court. 
(Ord. No. 90-3517, § 4, 12-13-90) 
Editor's note— Section 4 of Ord. No. 90-3517, adopted Dec. 13, 1990, amended Ch. 19 by adding § 19-20 thereto. Inasmuch as there existed a § 19-20, the editor has included the new provisions as § 19-20.1  
Sec. 19-21. - False certificates. 
(a)  No person shall make, issue or knowingly use any imitation or counterfeit of an official certificate of inspection. 
(b)  No person shall display or cause or permit to be displayed upon any vehicle any certificate of inspection and approval knowing the same to be fictitious or issued for another vehicle or issued without an inspection having been made. 
(c)  Whoever violates the provisions of subsection (a) or (b) above shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, shall be punished by a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisoned in jail for not more than six (6) months, or both, in the discretion of the court. 
(Ord. No. 90-3517, § 5, 12-13-90)  
Sec. 19-22. - Driver's license required. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate or drive a motor vehicle within the limits of the city without a driver's license as required by the laws of the state. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate or drive a motor vehicle within the city limits without having his license in his immediate possession at all times and the owner or operator shall display it upon demand of any police officer. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to permit or allow any other person to drive or operate any vehicle owned or controlled by him within the limits of the city, unless and until such person has been issued a license to do so as required by the laws of the state. 
(d)  Whoever violates the provisions of subsection (a), (b) or (c) above shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, shall be punished by a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisoned in jail for not more than six (6) months, or both, in the discretion of the court. 
(Ord. No. 90-3517, § 6, 12-13-90; Ord. No. 91-3554, § 1, 9-12-91)  
Sec. 19-23. - Operating vehicle with suspended or revoked driver's license. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate or drive a motor vehicle within the limits of the city with a driver's license which has been suspended or revoked by the appropriate authorities of the state of his domicile. 
(b)  Whoever violates the provisions of subsection (a) above shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, shall be fined not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00), or imprisoned for not more than six (6) months, or both, in the discretion of the court. 
(Ord. No. 90-3517, § 7, 12-13-90)  
Sec. 19-24. - Obedience to required traffic control devices displayed by school crossing guards; penalty. 
(a)  The driver of any vehicle shall obey the instructions of any school crossing guard displaying an official traffic control device at all times, subject to the exceptions granted the driver of an authorized emergency vehicle as provided for in Title 32 of the Revised Statutes of the State of Louisiana. 
(b)  Any person violating any of the provisions of this Ordinance shall be subject to a fine of up to five hundred dollars ($500.00) and/or six (6) months' imprisonment or both. 
(Ord. No. 95-3724, § 1, 9-14-95) 
Editor's note— Ordinance No. 95-3724, adopted Sep. 14, 1995, did not specifically amend this Code; hence, codification of § 1 of said ordinance as § 19-24 herein was at the editor's discretion.  
Secs. 19-25—19-29. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - POWERS AND DUTIES OF POLICE DEPARTMENT 
 
Sec. 19-30. - Enforcement duties generally. 
It shall be the duty of the police department to enforce the street traffic regulations of the city and all the vehicle laws of the state applicable to street traffic in the city, to make arrests for traffic violations, to investigate accidents and make reports thereon, and to cooperate with the other officers and departments of the city in the administration of the traffic laws and in developing ways and means to improve traffic conditions. 
(Code 1966, § 23-02)  
Sec. 19-31. - Enforcement authority generally; fire department officers at fires. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the officers of the police department or such officers as are assigned by the chief of police to enforce all street traffic laws of this city and all of the state vehicle laws applicable to street traffic in the city. 
(b)  Officers of the police department or such officers as are assigned by the chief of police are hereby authorized to direct all traffic by voice, hand or signal in conformance with traffic laws, provided that, in the event of a fire or other emergency or to expedite traffic or to safeguard pedestrians, officers of the police department may direct traffic as conditions may require notwithstanding the provisions of the traffic laws. 
(c)  Officers of the fire department, when at the scene of a fire, may direct or assist the police in directing traffic thereat, or in the immediate vicinity. 
(Code 1966, § 23-08)  
Sec. 19-32. - Administrative and experimental regulations. 
The chief of police is hereby empowered to make regulations necessary to make effective the provisions of the traffic ordinances of the city and to make and enforce temporary or experimental regulations to cover emergencies or special conditions. No such temporary or experimental regulation shall remain in effect for more than ninety (90) days. 
(Code 1966, § 23-07)  
Sec. 19-33. - Records of traffic violations. 
The police department shall keep a record of all violations of the traffic ordinances in the city, or of the state vehicle laws of which any person has been charged, together with a record of the final disposition of all such alleged offenses. Such records shall be so maintained as to show all types of violations and the total of each. Such records shall accumulate during at least a five-year period and from that time on the records shall be maintained complete for at least the most recent five-year period. All such records and reports shall be public records. 
(Code 1966, § 23-03) 
Cross reference— Reports as to violations at city hall and police station complex, § 19-69; reports as to violations at Morehouse General Hospital, § 19-89. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions as to state, R.S. 32:393.1; reporting to department of public safety, R.S. 32:398(F).  
Sec. 19-34. - Impounding vehicles. 
(a)  Members of the police department are hereby authorized to remove a vehicle from the street or highway to the nearest garage or other place of safety, or to a garage designated or maintained by the police department, or otherwise maintained by this city under the circumstances hereinafter enumerated: 
(1)  When any vehicle is left unattended upon any bridge, viaduct or causeway where such vehicle constitutes an obstruction to traffic. 
(2)  When a vehicle upon a street is so disabled as to constitute an obstruction to traffic and the persons in charge of the vehicle are by reason of physical injury incapacitated to such an extent as to be unable to provide for its custody and removal. 
(3)  When any vehicle is left unattended upon a street and is so parked illegally as to constitute a definite hazard or obstruction to the normal movement of traffic. 
(4)  When a vehicle is left unattended upon a street for such a length of time as to make it reasonable to conclude that the vehicle has been abandoned. 
(b)  Whenever an officer removes a vehicle from a street as authorized in this section and the officer knows or is able to ascertain from the registration records in the vehicle the name and address of the owner thereof, such officer shall immediately give or cause to be given notice in writing to such owner of the fact of such removal and the reasons therefor and the place of which such vehicle has been removed. 
(c)  The owner or operator of a vehicle so impounded shall pay the charges for moving and storing the vehicle upon claiming it. 
(Code 1966, § 23-38) 
Cross reference— Removal of junked vehicles, § 10-43 et seq. 
State Law reference— Impounding of vehicles authorized, R.S. 32:392.  
Sec. 19-35. - Designation of method of identifying funeral processions. 
The police department shall designate a type of pennant or other identifying insignia to be displayed upon, or other method to be employed to identify, the vehicles in funeral processions. 
(Code 1966, § 23-06)  
Sec. 19-36. - Determining intersections where stop required. 
The police department is hereby authorized to determine and designate intersections where particular hazards exist upon other than through streets and to determine whether vehicles shall stop at one (1) or more entrances to any such stop intersection, and shall erect a stop sign at every such place where a stop is required. 
(Code 1966, § 23-102)  
Sec. 19-37. - Designating crosswalks; marking traffic lanes. 
The police department is hereby authorized to designate and maintain, by appropriate devices, marks, or lines upon the surface of the roadway, crosswalks at intersections where there is particular danger to pedestrians crossing the roadway and at such other places as it may deem necessary and to mark lanes for traffic on street pavements at such places as it may deem advisable, consistent with the traffic ordinances of this city. 
(Code 1966, § 23-82)  
Secs. 19-38, 19-39. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - STOPPING, STANDING, PARKING[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Parking at city hall and police station complex, § 19-60 et seq.; parking at Morehouse General Hospital, § 19-80 et seq. 
 
Sec. 19-40. - Passenger and freight curb loading zone. 
(a)  No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle for any purpose or period of time other than for the expeditious loading of passengers in any place marked as a passenger curb loading zone during the hours when the regulations applicable to such curb loading zone are effective, and then only for a period not to exceed three (3) minutes. 
(b)  No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle for any purpose or length of time other than for the expeditious unloading and delivery or pickup and loading of materials in any place marked as a freight curb loading zone during hours when the provisions applicable to such zones are in effect. In no case shall the stop for loading and unloading of materials exceed thirty (30) minutes. 
(Code 1966, § 23-140)  
Sec. 19-41. - Bus stops. 
(a)  The driver of a bus shall not park upon any street in the business district at any place other than at a "bus stop." 
(b)  No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle other than a bus in a "bus stop" when any such "stop" has been officially designated and appropriately signed. 
(Code 1966, § 23-141)  
Sec. 19-42. - No-parking streets. 
No person shall park a vehicle of any nature on the following streets as hereinafter designated: 
(1)  Blanche Street extension from its intersection with Huey Street East to dead end; 
(2)  Smith Street from its intersection with King Street to its intersection with Huey Avenue. 
(Code 1966, § 23-142; Ord. No. 2721, § 1, 7-9-74)  
Sec. 19-43. - No-parking portions of streets. 
No person shall park a vehicle of any nature on the following portions of streets: 
(1)  North side of Collier Lane between Center Street and Freeland Avenue; 
(2)  The North side of Harrington Avenue between North Washington and North Marable. 
(Code 1966, § 23-142A; Ord. No. 2721, § 1, 7-9-74)  
Sec. 19-44. - Handicapped persons—Definition. 
The term "handicapped person" as used herein shall mean any person who has medically recognized impairments that for all practicable purposes confines such person to a wheelchair or causes such person to walk with difficulty or insecurity. 
(Code 1966, § 23-146; Ord. No. 3324, § 1, 8-12-86)  
Sec. 19-45. - Same—Designation of spaces; special stickers. 
The chief of police is hereby authorized to designate parking space locations on city streets and public parking facilities. Signs and/or markings shall be installed in conformance with the state manual on uniform traffic-control devices to indicate spaces for the handicapped. 
(1)  The chief of police is hereby authorized to determine the need for, and to designate, by proper signs and markings, certain parking spaces on public streets and in publicly owned parking facilities which are to be reserved for the exclusive use of vehicles bearing special stickers issued to a handicapped person or vehicles bearing special license plates issued by any state for handicapped persons or for disabled veterans when such vehicle is actually being operated by or for the transportation of a handicapped person. 
(2)  Owners of privately owned parking areas may designate certain spaces within those parking areas to be reserved for the exclusive use of vehicles bearing a special sticker issued to handicapped person or vehicles bearing special license plates issued by any state for handicapped persons or disabled veterans when such vehicle is actually being operated by or for the transportation of a handicapped person. 
(3)  Parking spaces for handicapped persons should be located as close as possible to elevators, ramps, walkways and entrances which are capable of being utilized by handicapped persons. Parking spaces should be located insofar as possible in such a manner that physically handicapped persons are not compelled to walk or wheel behind parked cars to reach entrances, ramps, walkways and/or elevators. 
(4)  The special stickers referred to in subsection (1) of this section shall be entitled "BASTROP SPECIAL VEHICLE IDENTIFICATION." Such sticker shall be of two (2) types: A red sticker shall be of a permanent nature and a green sticker shall be for a temporary period with an expiration date. The special stickers shall be affixed in the lower left-hand corner of the rear window of the vehicle for which it is issued. 
(5)  The special sticker may be obtained from the police department. 
(Code 1966, § 23-147; Ord. No. 3324, § 1, 8-12-86)  
Sec. 19-46. - Same—Penalties. 
(a)  No person shall park any vehicle in a mobility-impaired or handicapped designated parking space unless such person has a license plate or hang tag for the mobility-impaired issued pursuant to R.S. 47:463.4 or a properly displayed special parking card issued pursuant to R.S. 47:463.4.1. 
(b)  The law enforcement officer for the city who encounters a violator shall be authorized to issue a citation or take whatever law enforcement action is deemed necessary or both. Furthermore, when an individual found to be in violation of these provisions refuses a request by a law enforcement officer to move the vehicle found in violation, the officer shall be authorized to have such vehicle towed. 
(c)  The citation shall contain information concerning the nature, date, time, and location of the alleged violation, the state vehicle license plate number, and the make of vehicle. In those cases where a license plate is not visible or legible, the vehicle identification number shall be used in lieu of the state vehicle plate number. The citation shall also contain information advising the person charged of the manner and the time in which he may contest the violation charged in the citation. The citation shall also provide that a failure to timely answer or appear before a court of competent jurisdiction shall be considered a prima facie admission of the violation set forth in the citation, in which the court may assess the appropriate fine or fines and all penalties incidental thereto. 
(d)  The citation issued pursuant to the provisions of this subsection shall be personally served upon the operator of the vehicle by affixing the parking citation to the vehicle in a conspicuous place thereon. The original parking citation shall bear the name or initials and identification number of the issuing officer who shall affirm the truth of the facts set forth therein. An operator of a vehicle who is not the owner, but who uses or operates the vehicle with permission of the owner, expressed or implied, shall be considered the agent of the owner to receive the citation required to be served upon the operator or registered owner of a vehicle in accordance with the provisions of this subsection. When a citation is issued for an alleged violation of the laws governing parking in a mobility-impaired parking space, loading and unloading areas, access aisles, access ramps, and curb cuts, there shall be a rebuttable presumption that a person in whose name the vehicle is registered was the operator of the vehicle when the alleged violation was committed. 
(e)  In the event that the registered owner or operator of a vehicle drives the vehicle away from or in any manner leaves the site of the violation while the issuing officer is preparing the citation, or refuses service of the parking citation and drives away from or in any manner leaves the site of the violation, this fact shall be duly noted on the original and all copies of the parking citation. This original and all copies of a parking citation shall constitute a business record of the law enforcement agency issuing the citation and shall constitute prima facie evidence that the citation was issued and that an attempt at service was made in accordance with the provisions of this subsection. 
(f)  The first violation of the provisions of this subsection shall be punished by a fine of two hundred seventy-five dollars ($275.00). A subsequent violation shall be punished by a fine of five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(g)  If the violator is other than an individual, a fine of five hundred dollars ($500.00) shall be imposed. 
(h)  In addition to such fine, the violator may also be required to pay the towing fee and any storage costs which are incurred. 
(i)  The city shall recognize parking cards or other removable windshield placards and special license plates which have been issued by authorities of other states and countries for the purpose of identifying vehicles permitted to utilize parking spaces reserved for the mobility-impaired. 
(j)  No fine issued pursuant to this section shall be reduced or suspended. 
(Code 1966, § 23-148; Ord. No. 3324, § 1, 8-12-86; Ord. No. 05-4051, 3-10-05)  
Secs. 19-47—19-49. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - PARADES 
 
Sec. 19-50. - Definition. 
As used in this article, the term "parade" shall mean any parade, march, ceremony, show, exhibition, pageant or procession of any kind, or any similar display in or upon any street, park or other public place in the city. 
(Code 1966, § 23-22)  
Sec. 19-51. - Hours parading permitted. 
No parade shall be held in the city between the following hours: 7:00 a.m. and 9:00 a.m.; 11:30 a.m. and 1:15 p.m.; 4:40 p.m. and 5:30 p.m.; 6:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m., except that the chief of police may authorize a parade during such hours provided sufficient personnel and safety requirements are met. 
(Code 1966, § 23-23; Ord. No. 92-3610, § 1, 11-12-92)  
Sec. 19-52. - Exemption of funeral processions. 
No provision of this article other than section 19-53 shall apply to funeral processions. 
(Code 1966, § 23-24) 
Cross reference— Funeral identification, § 19-35.  
Sec. 19-53. - Permits—required; needed for parades and processions. 
(a)  No funeral procession or parade containing two hundred (200) or more persons or fifty (50) or more vehicles, excepting the armed forces of the United States, the military forces of the state, and the forces of the police and fire departments shall occupy, march, or proceed along any street except in accordance with a permit issued by the chief of police. 
(b)  No person shall engage in, participate in, form or start any parade, unless a parade permit shall have been obtained from the chief of police. 
(Code 1966, §§ 23-25, 23-26) 
State Law reference— Parade permits, R.S. 14:326.  
Sec. 19-54. - Same—time for application. 
(a)  In order for a parade to use United States Highway No. 165 between its intersection with Odom Street or Marable Street or Louisiana Highway No. 139 between its intersection with Cypress Avenue on the north and Hickory Avenue on the south must have applied for a parade permit not less than three (3) days, nor more than fourteen (14) days, before the date on which it is to conduct the parade. 
(b)  A person seeking to use any other public street of the city for a parade shall apply for a parade permit not less than twenty-four (24) hours before the time at which the parade will be conducted. 
(Code 1966, § 23-27)  
Sec. 19-55. - Same—Contents of application. 
The application for a parade permit shall set forth the following information: 
(1)  Name, address and telephone number of the person seeking to conduct such parade. 
(2)  If the parade is proposed to be conducted for, on behalf of, or by an organization, the name, address and telephone number of the headquarters of the organization, and of the authorized and responsible heads of such organization. 
(3)  The date on which the parade is to be conducted. 
(4)  The route to be traveled, and starting and termination points. 
(5)  The hours on which such parade will start and terminate. 
(6)  A statement as to whether the parade will occupy all or only a portion of the width of the streets proposed to be traversed. 
(7)  Location by streets of any assembly areas for such parade. 
(8)  The time in which such units of the parade will begin to assemble at any such assembly area or areas. 
(Code 1966, § 23-28)  
Sec. 19-56. - Same—Standard for issuance. 
(a)  The chief of police shall issue a permit as provided for hereunder, except when such officer finds that the parade will substantially interfere with the safe and orderly movement of traffic contiguous to its route. 
(b)  The conduct of the parade will require the diversion of so great a number of police officers of this municipality to properly police the line of movement and protect the marchers in the areas contiguous thereto as to prevent normal police protection to the city. 
(c)  The conduct of the parade is reasonably likely to cause injury to persons or property, and provoke disorderly conduct or create disturbance. 
(Code 1966, § 23-29)  
Sec. 19-57. - Same—Fee. 
There shall be paid at the time of filing the application for a parade permit a fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) together with such other amount as may be necessary to compensate the police department for required overtime pay for working the parade. 
(Code 1966, § 23-31; Ord. No. 3311, 4-8-86)  
Sec. 19-58. - Marching units. 
Marching units shall contain not more than twenty (20) persons abreast, and there must be an arm's length distance between the side and the front of each marcher. 
(Code 1966, § 23-30)  
Sec. 19-59. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - REGULATION AT CITY HALL AND POLICE STATION COMPLEX 
 
Sec. 19-60. - Scope. 
The following rules and regulations shall apply with respect to traffic and parking on the premises of the city hall and police station complex. 
(Ord. No. 2945, § 1, 7-10-79)  
Sec. 19-61. - Speed limit. 
No operator, driver, or person in charge of a motor vehicle shall exceed the speed limit of ten (10) miles per hour upon the premises of the city hall and police station complex. 
(Ord. No. 2945, § 1(1), 7-10-79)  
Sec. 19-62. - Stop at exits. 
No operator, driver, or person in charge of a motor vehicle shall exit from the premises of the city hall and police station complex at its intersections with South Franklin Street or at its intersection with Jefferson Avenue without having come to a full stop in obedience to stop signs controlling such intersections. 
(Ord. No. 2945, § 1(2), 7-10-79)  
Sec. 19-63. - No-parking zones. 
No operator, driver, or person in charge of a motor vehicle shall stop or park such vehicle in the no-parking zones located in front of the two (2) entrances to the complex on the south side thereof, or the two (2) entrance areas on the east side thereof. 
(Ord. No. 2945, § 1(3), 7-10-79)  
Sec. 19-64. - Handicapped parking. 
No operator, driver, or person in charge of a motor vehicle shall stop or park such vehicle at the designated locations for handicapped persons unless such operator, driver, or person in charge of a motor vehicle meets the qualifications of a handicapped person. 
(Ord. No. 2945, § 1(4), 7-10-79)  
Sec. 19-65. - Placement of markers; parking restrictions. 
In authorized two-hour free parking zones, fifteen-minute parking zones, reserved parking zones, and handicapped parking zones, the chief of police shall cause markings to be placed upon wooden blocks in front of the curbs and cause markings to be painted upon the adjacent street for the purpose of designating the parking space and each vehicle shall park within the lines and only in the spaces marked for fifteen-minute parking, two-hour parking, and handicapped parking. No person shall park such vehicle in the reserved parking area unless in the space which has been reserved for such vehicle. No person shall park any vehicle in such a position that the same shall not be entirely within the areas designated by the painted lines. Each space shall be identified numerically. The hours during the day when such parking may be used or between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m. on any day, Sundays and legal holidays excepted. 
(Ord. No. 2945, § 1(5), 7-10-79)  
Sec. 19-66. - Overtime parking in authorized two-hour parking zone or authorized fifteen-minute parking zone. 
Each vehicle parking in a space within the area designated either as a designated two-hour free parking zone or a designated fifteen-minute free parking zone shall not remain parked in any such parking space beyond the authorized limit and in the event a vehicle remains in the designated space for more than the time allotted then in that event such vehicle shall be considered as parked overtime and such shall constitute a violation of this article and the owner or operator thereof shall be punished as hereinafter set forth. 
(Ord. No. 2945, § 1(6), 7-10-79)  
Sec. 19-67. - Unauthorized parking in a reserved parking zone. 
Each vehicle parking in a reserved parking area without proper authorization shall constitute a violation of this article and the owner or operator thereof shall be punished as hereinafter set forth. 
(Ord. No. 2945, § 1(7), 7-10-79)  
Sec. 19-68. - Unauthorized parking in a no-parking zone. 
Each vehicle parking in a no-parking area without proper authorization shall constitute a violation of this article and the owner or operator thereof shall be punished as hereinafter set forth. 
(Ord. No. 2945, § 1(8), 7-10-79)  
Sec. 19-69. - Procedure for handling of violation of provisions relating to reserved parking, two-hour free parking, fifteen-minute parking, no-parking, and handicapped parking, and the penalties therefor. 
(a)  Any person who shall violate any of the above provisions relating to parking and any person who aids, abets, or assists therein shall, upon conviction thereof, be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of the police officers of this city, acting in accordance with instructions issued by the governing body, to report: 
(1)  The number of each parking space which indicated that the vehicle occupying the parking space is or has been parked in violation in any of the above provisions. 
(2)  The state license number of such vehicle. 
(3)  The time such vehicle is found parking in violation of any of the above provisions. 
(4)  Any other facts or knowledge which is necessary to a thorough understanding of the circumstances attending such violation. 
(c)  Each such police officer shall also attach to such vehicle a notice to the owner or operator thereof that such vehicle has been parked in violation of a provision of this article and instructing such owner or operator to report to the office of the clerk of the city court in regards to such violation. 
(d)  Each such owner or operator shall, within twenty-four (24) hours of the time when the violation occurred, pay to the clerk of the city court, as a penalty for and in full satisfaction of such violation, the sum of one dollar ($1.00). The failure of such owner or operator to make such payment within such twenty-four (24) hours shall render such owner or operator subject to a fine for contempt of court. 
(Ord. No. 2945, § 1(9), 7-10-79)  
Secs. 19-70—19-79. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VI. - REGULATION AT MOREHOUSE GENERAL HOSPITAL 
 
Sec. 19-80. - Scope. 
The following rules and regulations shall apply with respect to traffic and parking on the premises of Morehouse General Hospital. 
(Ord. No. 2992, 5-20-80)  
Sec. 19-81. - Speed limit. 
No operator, driver, or person in charge of a motor vehicle shall exceed the speed limit of five (5) miles per hour upon the parking area and premises of Morehouse General Hospital. 
(Ord. No. 2992, § 1, 5-20-80)  
Sec. 19-82. - Stop at exits. 
No operator, driver, or person in charge of a motor vehicle shall exit from the premises of Morehouse General Hospital at its intersections with Walnut Street on the east and west side of the existing building of Morehouse General Hospital or at its intersection with Durham Street on the south side of the existing building without having come to a full stop in obedience to the stop signs controlling such intersections. 
(Ord. No. 2992, § 2, 5-20-80)  
Sec. 19-83. - Stopping in the emergency drive. 
No operator, driver, or person in charge of a motor vehicle shall stop or park such vehicle in the emergency drive of Morehouse General Hospital except for the purpose of loading or unloading a patient. 
(Ord. No. 2992, § 3, 5-20-80)  
Sec. 19-84. - Entering the emergency drive. 
No operator, driver, or person in charge of a motor vehicle shall enter the emergency drive of Morehouse General Hospital except from Durham Street. 
(Ord. No. 2992, § 4, 5-20-80)  
Sec. 19-85. - Stopping in area reserved for doctors. 
No operator, driver, or person in charge of a motor vehicle, except authorized doctors, shall stop or park such vehicle in the area reserved for doctors presently located on the southwest corner of Morehouse General Hospital premises. 
(Ord. No. 2992, § 5, 5-20-80)  
Sec. 19-86. - Handicapped parking. 
No operator, driver, or person in charge of a motor vehicle shall stop or park such vehicle at the designated locations for handicapped persons or other such areas as designated by the hospital administrator and chief of police as the need arises unless such operator, driver, or person in charge of a motor vehicle meets the qualifications of the designated parking area. 
(Ord. No. 2992, § 6, 5-20-80)  
Sec. 19-87. - Compliance with signs. 
No operator, driver or person in charge of a motor vehicle shall park such vehicle in any drive, accessway or roadway located on the premises of Morehouse General Hospital except as expressly permitted by signs designating same. 
(Ord. No. 2992, § 7, 5-20-80)  
Sec. 19-88. - Removal of unattended vehicle. 
The chief of police or the chief's designated representatives are authorized, upon request by the hospital administrator of Morehouse General Hospital, to remove any unattended vehicle found parked or stopped where parking is prohibited and are authorized to impound such vehicle until the owner thereof has paid the wrecker fee for the removal of such vehicle from the hospital parking area to the city impoundment area, and paid a reasonable fee for the storage of such vehicle not to exceed three dollars ($3.00) per day. 
(Ord. No. 2992, § 8, 5-20-80)  
Sec. 19-89. - Report of violations; citation; penalties. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the police officers of this city to report: 
(1)  The state license number of such vehicle. 
(2)  The time such vehicle is found parking in violation of any of the provisions of sections 19-83, 19-85, 19-86 and 19-87. 
(3)  Any other facts or knowledge which is necessary to a thorough understanding of the circumstances attending such violation. 
(b)  Each such police officer shall also attach to such vehicle a notice to the owner or operator thereof that such vehicle has been parked in violation of a provision of this article and instructing such owner or operator to report to the office of the clerk of the city court in regard to such violation. Each such owner or operator shall, within twenty-four (24) hours of the time the violation occurred, pay to the clerk of the city court as a penalty for and in full satisfaction of such violation, the sum of three dollars ($3.00). The failure of such owner or operator to make such payment within such twenty-four (24) hours shall render such owner or operator subject to a fine for contempt of court. 
(c)  Any vehicle may be ticketed for such violation for each two (2) hours of such violation as above noted; provided, however, that a maximum of three (3) tickets may be issued in a twenty-four-hour period starting with the time of the first violation thereof. 
(Ord. No. 2992, § 9, 5-20-80)  
Chapter 20 - VEHICLES FOR HIRE[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference— Authority to regulate taxicabs, § 5(39). 
 
Sec. 20-1. - Definitions. 
As used in this chapter, the following terms shall have the respective meanings ascribed to them: 
Dispatcher's log: A daily record prepared by the taxicab operator (through such operator's dispatcher or other assigned representative) of all trips made by the driver, showing time and place of origin, destination, number of passengers and the amount of fare of each trip. 
Limousine: Any motor vehicle used for the transportation of passengers, except those requiring a litter, for hire between fixed termini, where the destination is not controlled by the passengers. 
Operator's permit: A certificate issued by the city clerk certifying that the holder is authorized to operate a taxicab, fleet of taxicabs, limousine, or fleet of limousines upon the streets of the city. 
Owner, operator: Any person who owns or controls the use of a taxicab. 
Taxicab, taxi, cab: Any motor vehicle used for the transportation of passengers, except those requiring a litter, for hire, not operated on a fixed route, to a destination that is controlled by the passengers. 
(Code 1966, § 23-179; Ord. No. 87-3361, 8-11-87; Ord. No. 87-3380, § 1, 11-10-87)  
Sec. 20-2. - Owner's or operator's permit—Required; rules and regulations; display; renewal. 
(a)  No owner or operator of a taxicab shall permit it to be operated upon the streets of the city without first obtaining a permit therefor from the city clerk or designated representative. 
(b)  The city clerk or designated representative is hereby given authority to promulgate such reasonable rules and regulations as may be necessary to enforce the provisions of this chapter. 
(c)  The operator's permit issued by the city clerk or designated representative shall be conspicuously affixed or displayed at the taxicab operator's place of business, headquarters or dispatch office. 
(d)  All operators shall renew their permit each year, on or before January thirty-first, by payment of the appropriate fee and filing of application as required by the city clerk or designated representative and in this chapter. 
(Code 1966, § 23-180; Ord. No. 87-3361, 8-11-87)  
Sec. 20-3. - Same—Application. 
Application for permits shall be made to the city clerk upon the forms prescribed by the city clerk and shall include: 
(1)  The name and address of the owner or operator of the taxicabs. 
(2)  A description of each taxicab, including the make, model, year of manufacture, Louisiana license number for the current year, motor and chassis number and a statement regarding the length of time the vehicle has been in use. 
(3)  The location and description of the places from which it is intended to operate. 
(Code 1966, § 23-181; Ord. No. 87-3361, 8-11-87)  
Sec. 20-4. - Same—Qualifications. 
In determining whether a permit shall be issued, the city clerk or designated representative shall give due regard to: 
(1)  Proof of financial responsibility and the establishment and maintenance of a bona fide office within the corporate limits from which the service is offered. 
(2)  The experience that the applicant has had in rendering services in the city, the past experience of the applicant in prompt adjustment of claims and in payment of judgments, if any, arising out of the operation of such vehicles. Experience is not a requirement if subsection (1) of this section is met and the financial ability of the applicant to respond in damages is sufficiently demonstrated. 
(3)  That insurance as required by section 20-6 has been secured. 
(4)  The character and condition of the vehicle to be used as determined after inspection as required by this chapter. 
(5)  That the applicant, owner or any partner has not been convicted of a felony under the laws of the United States, this state, or other state or country and has not served any part of a sentence therefor within five (5) years before the date of filing of the application. 
(6)  That the applicant, owner or any partner has not been convicted in this or in any other state or by the United States or any country of prostitution, soliciting for prostitution, pandering, letting premises for prostitution, gambling, illegally dealing in narcotics or any other misdemeanor involving moral turpitude, within two (2) years before the date of filing of the application. 
(7)  That subsections (5) and (6) are complied with and if a violation is found by the police department, then the city clerk or duly authorized representative shall deny or revoke the applicant's permit. 
(8)  That the applicant has or intends to locate such person's place of business, stand or dispatch office within the corporate limits of the city. 
(9)  That all requirements of this chapter and all other applicable laws and ordinances have been complied with. 
(Code 1966, § 23-182; Ord. No. 87-3361, 8-11-87)  
Sec. 20-5. - Same—Denial, suspension or revocation; appeal. 
(a)  Every owner or operator granted a permit under this chapter shall comply with all parish, state and federal laws. Failure to do so will justify the city clerk or duly authorized representative suspending or revoking the permit. 
(b)  The city clerk or duly authorized representative may deny any applicant's permit whenever, in the exercise of reasonable and sound discretion, and after notice and affording the applicant a hearing thereon, it shall be determined that the applicant is not a fit and proper person to have such permit. The applicant may appeal within ten (10) days from such denial to the governing body to determine if such denial is justified. 
(c)  The city clerk or duly authorized representative is hereby given authority to suspend any permit issued under this chapter for failure or refusal to comply with the provisions of this chapter, such suspension to last for a period of not more than thirty (30) days. The city clerk or duly authorized representative is hereby given authority to revoke any permit for failure to comply with the provisions of this chapter; however, the permit may not be revoked unless the holder has received notice and has had an opportunity to present evidence on such holder's behalf. 
(d)  Whenever a person who shall have been issued a permit under this chapter shall be charged in court with a felony or with a violation of this chapter, the city clerk is hereby given authority to suspend the permit pending final disposition of the charges and to revoke same upon conviction thereof. 
(Code 1966, § 23-188; Ord. No. 87-3361, 8-11-87)  
Sec. 20-6. - Insurance. 
(a)  Before any permit is issued hereunder, the applicant shall file with the city clerk or duly authorized representative a certificate of public liability insurance issued by an insurance company qualified to do business in the state which shall contain the following conditions and stipulations: 
(1)  The term of such insurance policy shall be for a minimum of six (6) months. 
(2)  The insurance policy shall provide not less than the following limits of liability: for each accident causing bodily injury (including death at any time resulting therefrom) fifteen thousand dollars ($15,000.00) for each person, thirty thousand dollars ($30,000.00) for each accident, and twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) for property damages sustained in any one (1) accident. 
(3)  Such policy shall by its terms provide that it may not be cancelled except after ten (10) days' written notice thereof to the city clerk. 
(b)  Any owner or operator who fails to secure another policy of liability insurance prior to cancellation of an existing one shall automatically, and without notice of hearing, suffer suspension of the permit until such time as such certificate of policy has been filed with the city clerk or duly authorized representative. 
(c)  Any person who operates a taxicab without having such liability insurance in force shall be guilty of a violation of this chapter and shall be punished as provided in section 1-8 of this Code. 
(d)  Any person who does not have such liability insurance in force at the time of making application must obtain a written statement from a qualified insurance company, signed by an authorized officer of such company, stating that the applicant will be accepted for liability coverage under the terms of this chapter with respect to each vehicle for which an application has been made, if the application is approved. This subsection does not exempt operators from the requirements of subsection (b) above. 
(Code 1966, § 23-184; Ord. No. 87-3361, 8-11-87; Ord. No. 87-3380, § 2, 11-10-87; Ord. No. 16-4238A, 3-15-16 )  
Sec. 20-7. - Qualifications for taxi drivers. 
Each taxi driver shall certify that such driver meets the following qualifications: 
(1)  Has current vehicle chauffeur's license issued by the state. 
(2)  Has not been convicted of a felony or served any part of a sentence therefor under the laws of the United States, this state or other state or country within five (5) years before the date of the filing of the application. 
(3)  Has not been convicted in this or any other state or by the United States or any country of soliciting for prostitution, pandering, letting premises for prostitution, gambling, illegally dealing in narcotics, driving or operating a vehicle while intoxicated, four (4) or more moving traffic violations, or any misdemeanor involving moral turpitude within two (2) years before the date of filing of the application. 
(4)  Is not addicted to the use of intoxicating liquor, does not use any narcotic drugs and is not suffering from any disease or infirmity which might make such person an unsafe or unsatisfactory driver. 
(Code 1966, § 23-183; Ord. No. 87-3361, 8-11-87)  
Sec. 20-8. - Vehicle equipment; inspection. 
Each taxicab authorized by permit under this chapter shall be equipped with a serviceable fire extinguisher and a first aid kit and shall be at all times, when operating, in proper safe mechanical condition, and shall have a current vehicle inspection sticker affixed thereto issued by the state. 
(Code 1966, § 23-185; Ord. No. 87-3361, 8-11-87)  
Sec. 20-9. - Designation of taxicabs and keeping of dispatcher's log. 
(a)  All taxicabs owned by one (1) person or operated under one (1) operator's permit shall have the same identifying design, monogram or insignia. 
(b)  Any operator of a taxicab shall designate the same as a taxicab by displaying the name and dispatch telephone number, and such vehicle shall bear a sign or other device indicating that it is a taxicab for hire and have for-hire taxicab license plates issued by the state. 
(c)  Each operator shall maintain through such operator's dispatcher or an assigned representative a dispatcher's log upon which shall be recorded all trips made each day, showing time and place of origin and destination of each trip and amount of fare. All dispatcher's logs shall be preserved and retained for a period of one (1) year and shall be available upon request by the city clerk, chief of police, or their representatives, or any duly authorized law enforcement officer; and any other person or agency, provided such person or agency has been authorized in writing by the chief of police or the city clerk. 
(d)  Every taxicab operated under this chapter shall have a card posted on the inside of the taxicab in full view of all passengers of the taxicab and enclosed in a frame with a transparent covering showing the unit number and a statement indicating that the rates are prefixed and customers are encouraged to request from the driver an on-the-spot rate check from the operator's dispatcher. The driver shall be issued a receipt upon request. 
(e)  Every taxicab driver shall conspicuously post such person's driver's license in order that the passenger can ascertain that the driver and person pictured on the license are one and the same in order that the passenger can identify the driver if necessary. 
(Code 1966, § 23-186; Ord. No. 87-3361, 8-11-87; Ord. No. 87-3380, § 3, 11-10-87)  
Sec. 20-10. - Designation of limousines. 
Any owner or operator of a limousine service which regularly utilizes the streets within the city shall meet all the requirements of this chapter pertaining to taxicabs except as provided in section 20-9, subsections (a) and (b). 
(1)  Any vehicle operating as a limousine shall have the word "Limousine" displayed conspicuously on each side of the vehicle in either magnetic or painted letters; directly below the word "Limousine" shall appear the operator's permit number in magnetic or painted letters. 
(2)  Every limousine operated under this chapter shall have a rate card posted on the inside of the vehicle, in full view of all passengers of the vehicle, enclosed in a frame with a transparent card showing the unit number and the rates charged by the operator. Upon request, the driver shall issue a receipt upon payment of rate by passenger. 
(Code 1966, § 23-187; Ord. No. 87-3361, 8-11-87)  
Sec. 20-11. - Ambulance service. 
Tubb's Ambulance Service is hereby designated as the first responder for purposes of the Emergency 911 Telephone System in the city and surrounding area and shall be installed and designated as such unless the person requesting such ambulance service specifies in the initial call another ambulance service by name. 
(Ord. No. 96-3742, § 1, 3-21-96) 
Editor's note— Ordinance No. 96-3742, adopted March 21, 1996, did not specifically amend this Code; hence, codification of § 1 of said ordinance as § 20-11 herein was at the editor's discretion.

Sec. 1.1 General Provisions 


1.1.1 Title 
This chapter shall be known as the “zoning development code for the City of Bastrop, Louisiana" and may be cited and referred to as “this zoning develop­ment code.” 

1.1.2 Authority 
This zoning development code is adopted pursuant to the authority granted by Louisiana Revised Statute 33:4780.04 et. seq. 

1.1.3 Applicability 
The provisions of this zoning development code apply to the development of all land within the City of Bastrop. No development shall be undertaken without prior authorization pursuant to this zoning development code. 

1.1.4 E.ecO ve Date 
This zoning development code was adopted on December 13,2010, and became e.ective on July 1, 2011. 

1.1.5 Purpose 
A. 	This zoning development code is adopted for the purpose of guiding devel­opment in accordance with the City of Bastrop's  Master Land Use Plan and existing and future needs of the City of Bastrop in order to protect, promote and improve the public health, safety, morals, convenience, order, appear­ance, prosperity and general welfare. 
B. 	The regulations hereby enacted are designed to exercise the full range of authority available to the City of Bastrop under Louisiana law to: 
1. 	
Promote the public health, safety and general welfare, while recogniz­ing the rights of real property owners, by adopting a comprehensive zoning ordinance and providing for administrative procedures and development standards. 

2. 	
Help achieve the goals, objectives and policies of the Master Land Use Plan. 

3. 	
Prevent the overcrowding of land and avoid undue concentration or dispersal of population by creating zoning districts consistent with the 


SEC. 1.1 GENERAL PROVISIONS 
1.1.6 Intent 
character of each area within the City of Bastrop by adopting an O.cial Zoning Map. 
4. 	
Provide the most bene.cial relationship between the uses of land and buildings and the circulation of automobile tra.  c and pedestri­ans throughout the City of Bastrop, and to secure safety from natural disaster, .re, and other dangers by providing for the proper location of streets, sidewalks, and buildings. 

5. 	
Provide for a range of open spaces through the most e.  cient design and layout of the land. 

6. 	
Carry out such other purposes in the public interest as may be speci.­cally cited in this zoning development code. 



1.1.6 Intent 
This zoning development code is intended to provide a mechanism for imple­menting the following goals: 
A. 	Protecting the natural infrastructure and visual character of the region. 
B. 	Creating a range of housing opportunities and choices. 
C. 	Creating mixed-use, walkable neighborhoods. 
D. 	Encouraging community and stakeholder collaboration. 
E. 	Fostering distinctive, attractive communities with a strong sense of place. 
F. 	Making development decisions predictable, fair and cost e.ective. 
G. 	Mixing land uses. 
H. 	Preserving open space, farmland, natural beauty and critical environmental areas. 
I. 	Providing a variety of transportation choices, and transportation corridors that are planned in coordination with land use. 
J. 	Strengthening and directing development towards existing communities. 
K. 	Taking advantage of compact building design where infrastructure is in place. 
ARTICLE 1. GENERAL 
1.1.7 Minimum Requirements 

1.1.7 Minimum Requirements 
The requirements of this zoning development code shall be considered as the minimum requirements for the promotion of the public health, safety and general welfare. 

1.1.8 Con.icO ng Provisions 
A. 	All development must comply with relevant Federal and State regulations. Whenever any provision of this zoning development code imposes a greater requirement or a higher standard than is required in any Federal or State statute or regulation, the provisions of this zoning development code shall govern unless preempted by Federal or State law. 
B. 	It is not the intent of this zoning development code to interfere with or annul any easements, covenants, or other agreements between parties; provided that where this zoning development code imposes a greater restriction upon the use and dimensions of buildings, structures, or land, or requires larger open spaces than are imposed or required by other ordinanc­es, regulations, or permits, or by easements, covenants, or agreements, the provisions of this zoning development code shall govern, except where expressly quali.ed in this zoning development code. 

1.1.9 Severability 
Should any provision of this zoning development code be decided by the courts to be unconstitutional or invalid, that decision shall not a.ect the validity of this zon­ing development code other than the part decided to be unconstitutional or invalid.

2.1.4 Building Types 
Sec. 2.1 Code Approach 





2.1.1 Generally 
This zoning development code is organized around a hierarchal framework from the city level to the individual building site. The three organizing devices are: 
1. 
Context Areas; 

2. 
Zoning Districts; and 

3.
 Building Types 



2.1.2 Context Areas 
A. Context Areas 
Context areas are derived from the existing and desired characteristics of the City of Bastrop. The context areas are distinguished from one another by their overall physical and functional characteristics including but not limited to: 
1. 
General character; 

2. 
Regional growth areas; 

3.
 Zoning districts; 

4. 
Building type, placement, height and coverage; 

5. 
Street, alley, and block patterns; and 

6. 
Parking and mobility options. 


B. Context Area Map 
The boundaries of the context areas are established and shown on the "City of Bastrop Context Area Map" and may be cited and referred to as the "O.cial Context Area Map". The O.cial Context Area Map is hereby made part of this zoning development code. All notations, references and other information shown shall have the same force and e.ect as if fully set forth or described in this zoning development code. The Context Area Map must be properly at­tested and kept on .le by the Administrator. 

2.1.3 Zoning Districts 
This zoning development code further details each context area by identifying a number of zoning districts permitted within each context area. The zoning districts are intended to be strategically applied to create development patterns and a built envi­ronment that is complementary of the characteristics of the respective context area. 

2.1.4 Building Types 
This zoning development code also uses building types to explain how buildings and structures relate to their lots, surrounding buildings and structures, street and alley rights-of-way, and the overall public realm. Each context area contains a menu of illustrated building forms and associated standards that control mass, scale, height, and other physical characteristics of buildings appropriate to each context area. 
2.2.1 Context Areas Established 
Sec. 2.2 Context Areas 


2.2.1 Context Areas Established 
Context areas are used to establish the character of existing or proposed neighborhoods. Each context area sets standards for development appropriate to the type of neighborhood anticipated. This zoning development code is organized around the four context areas established below. 

Suburban 
Suburban consists of low-density, primarily residential areas typically located outside the urban core of a city.  Single-family detached housing is predominant with some opportunities for at­tached housing. Commercial activity is typically concen­trated in nodes and corridors along major roadways. 
Urban 
Urban consists of medium density areas typically located adjacent to the center of a city.  Diverse housing types are present such as single-family houses, attached houses and apartments. Com­mercial activity is concentrat­ed along major roadways and at neighborhood nodes and may be of a mixed use type. 
Center 
Center is typically the highest density, highest activity area of a city with the greatest variety of uses. Often it encompasses a city's down­town. Civic, cultural, com­mercial, retail and o.  ce uses are often present. Attached buildings frequently form a continuous street wall. 
Special 
Special consists of large scale civic, institutional, heavy industrial and conser­vation areas which do not .t easily into other contexts. These uses may occur within other context areas in smaller concentrations.

SEC. 2.5 ZONING MAP 
2.5.1 Zoning Map Incorporated 
Sec. 2.5 Zoning Map 





2.5.1 Zoning Map Incorporated 
The boundaries of the zoning districts are established and shown on the "City of Bastrop Zoning District Map" and may be cited and referred to as the "O.  cial Zoning Map". The O.cial Zoning Map is hereby made part of this zoning development code. All notations, references and other information shown shall have the same force and e.ect as if fully set forth or described in this zoning development code. The O.cial Zoning Map must be properly attested and kept on .le by the Administrator. 

2.5.2 O.cial Zoning Map InterpretaOon 
A. 	In the event that any uncertainty exists with respect to the intended boundaries as shown on the O.cial Zoning Map, the Administrator is authorized to inter­pret the O.  cial Zoning Map. 
B. 	Where uncertainty exists as to the boundaries of any district shown on the Of­.cial Zoning Map, the following rules shall apply: 
1. 	
The boundaries are the center lines of the streets, alleys, waterways and rights-of-way, unless otherwise indicated. Where designation of a boundary line on the O.cial Zoning Map coincides with the location of a street, alley, waterway or right-of-way, the center line of the street, alley, water way or right-of-way shall be construed to be the boundary of such district. 

2. 	
Where the boundaries do not coincide with the location of streets, alleys, waterways and rights-of-way but do coincide with parcel or lot lines, such parcel or lot lines shall be construed to be the boundaries. 

3. 	
Where the boundaries do not coincide with the location of streets, alleys, waterways, rights-of-way, parcel or lot lines, the boundary shall be deter­mined by the use of the scale shown on the O.  cial Zoning Map. 

4. 	
In any property split into more than one zoning district, the lines on the O.­cial Zoning Map shall be determined by use of the scale shown on the O.cial Zoning Map. 


C. 	Upon dispute of the Administrator’s interpretation, the applicant may ap­peal the decision to the Board of Adjustment as set forth in 16.2.6, Appeal of Administrative Decision.

Article 16 

3.1.5 Parking 


3.1.1 General Character 
The Suburban context consists of low-density, primarily residential areas, typi­cally located outside the urban core of a city. Single-family detached housing is predominant with some opportunities for multifamily attached housing. Com­mercial activity may be concentrated in nodes or along major roadways. Larger lot sizes allow most buildings to have prominent front and back yards. 

3.1.2 Zoning Districts 
The Suburban context allows for a wide variety of residential, commercial and special purpose districts at Suburban intensities. 

3.1.3 Building Type and Dimensions 
Residential buildings are between one and two stories in height. Residences typically have landscaped front setbacks and building coverage of the lot is relatively low. Commercial structures are also between one and two stories in height. Commercial buildings may be built to the street or setback deep enough to allow for a mix of landscaping and parking. 

3.1.4 Block Pa.erns 
Block shapes and sizes vary signi.cantly within this context, often unrelated to form or use. The typical block pattern includes attached sidewalks, street and surface parking, and generous landscaping between the street and building fac­es. Residential access is typically a direct connection to a street facing garage or carport. Commercial access is typically a shared drive to a surface parking lot. Alleys are atypical but are encouraged in new development. 


3.1.5 Parking 
Parking is provided on-street and on surface lots. Limited surface parking is permitted between the building and the street but parking is primarily located to the side and rear of buildings. 
SEC. 3.2 ZONING DISTRICTS 
3.2.1 Suburban ResidenOal Single-Family (S-RS-15, -10, -6) 
Sec. 3.2 Zoning Districts 
The following zoning districts are established to carry out the provisions of this zoning development code and may be used within the Suburban Context as ap­plied to property as set forth on the O.  cial Zoning Map. 



3.2.1 Suburban ResidenOal Single-Family (S-RS-15, -10, -6) 
A. 	The Suburban Residential Single-Family districts are intended to accommo­date single-family detached houses on individual lots. These districts should be applied in areas where the land-use pattern is predominately single-family residential or where such land use pattern is desired in the future. 
B. 	Three S-RS districts are allowed in the Suburban Context: S-RS-15, S-RS-10, and S-RS-6. The S-RS districts di.er primarily as to the minimum lot size al­lowed for a single-family house within the district. 

1. 	
The S-RS-15 district generally requires a minimum lot size of 15,000 square feet. 

2. 	
The S-RS-10 district generally requires a minimum lot size of 10,000 square feet. 


3. 	
The S-RS-6 district generally requires a minimum lot size of 6,000 square feet. 



3.2.2 Suburban ResidenO al MulO family (S-RM-2) 
The Suburban Residential Multifamily district is intended to accommodate existing or proposed development where the land-use pattern is a mix of single-family, two-family and multifamily housing. The S-RM-2 district is not intended to provide for large areas exclusively dominated by multifamily but provide for neighborhoods that successfully integrate single-family, two-family and multi­family together. The S-RM-2 district allows buildings up to two stories in height. 


3.2.3 Suburban Commercial Corridor (S-CC-2) 

The Suburban Commercial Corridor district is intended to balance the need for safe, active, and pedestrian-scaled, diverse areas with the need for limited parking be­tween buildings and the street. While the S-CC-2 district allows buildings to be built to the street edge, the district addresses development opportunities along auto-domi­nated corridors where it is infeasible or impractical to require buildings to be built to the street edge. The S-CC-2 district is intended to be located within convenient travel­ing distance from the multiple neighborhoods they are intended to serve. The S-CC-2 district allows buildings with up to two stories in height. 
3-2 	| City of Bastrop 
ARTICLE 3. SUBURBAN 


3.2.4 Suburban Light Industrial (S-LI) 
The Suburban Light Industrial district is intended to accommodate light manu­facturing, research and development, limited warehousing, wholesale and upper story residential uses. Development should be operated in a relatively clean and quiet manner, and should not be obnoxious to nearby residential or commercial uses. Buildings may be either pulled up to the street or setback to allow some parking between the building and the street. The S-LI district allows buildings up to 3 stories in height. 

3.2.5 Suburban Heavy Industrial (S-HI) 
The Suburban Heavy Industrial district is intended to accommodate higher-impact manufacturing and industrial uses, including extractive and waste-related uses, that by their nature create a nuisance, and which are not properly associat­ed with or are compatible with nearby residential or commercial neighborhoods, unless properly scaled, screened, and bu.ered. The S-HI district allows buildings up to 3 stories in height. 

3.2.6 Suburban Community (S-CD) 
The Suburban Community district  is intended to provide for civic and institution­al uses that do not readily assimilate into neighborhoods of residential or mixed use building types. The S-CD district is also intended to accommodate the active and recreational needs of residents and to promote recreational uses that are compatible with surrounding land uses, and to protect natural resources. 

3.2.7 Suburban Planned Development (S-PD) 
The Suburban Planned Development district provides .exibility in development in exchange for a more desirable use of the land, a more coherent and coordi­nated development, and a better physical environment than would be pos­sible under one of the other Suburban context base zoning districts. Planned developments are intended as a tool to allow innovative and imaginative design that will promote amenities beyond those expected in conventional suburban developments and conservation of open space and natural areas. Planned developments within the Suburban Context may remain consistent with the established suburban pattern or may be more urban in design. 
Sec. 3.3 Allowed Uses 
3.3.1 General Provisions 
A.	 Use Categories 
1. 	
In order to regulate use, categories of uses have been established. 

2. 	
Use categories provide a systematic basis for assigning land uses to ap­propriate categories with other, similar uses. 

3. 	
Use categories classify land uses and activities based on common functional, product, or physical characteristics. Characteristics include the type and amount of activity, the hours of operation, the type of cus­tomers or residents, how goods or services are sold or delivered, likely impact on surrounding properties, and site conditions. 


B. Principal Uses 
Allowed principal uses by district are listed in the Allowed Use Table below. Principal uses are grouped into use categories outlined in Sec. 7.2, Use Categories. The uses listed are not an exhaustive list. When a proposed use is not identi.ed on the allowed use table or in Article 7, Use Provisions, the Administrator may determine that the proposed use is su.  ciently similar to an identi. ed use. 
C. Accessory Uses 
Accessory uses are allowed in conjunction with an allowed principal use as set forth in Sec. 7.8, Accessory Uses . 
D.	 Temporary Uses 
Temporary uses are allowed as set forth in Sec. 7.9, Temporary Uses . 
SEC. 3.3 ALLOWED USES 
3.3.2 Allowed Use Table 


3.3.2 Allowed Use Table 
The allowed use table establishes the uses allowed within each district and any conditions or use standards associated with each use. The allowed use table key is set forth below. 
A. 	Allowed by Right (.) 
Indicates a use is allowed by right in the respective district subject to any use standard. Such use is also subject to all other applicable requirements of this zoning development code. 

B. Approved Concept Plan (¼) 
Indicates a use may be permitted in the respective district only where approved by the Bastrop City Council as part of an approved concept plan in accordance with Sec. 16.2.12, Planned Development. Unless otherwise modi.ed by the Bastrop City Council, uses allowed as part of an approved concept plan are subject to all other applicable requirements of this zoning development code, including all applicable use standards. 

C. Special Use Permit (.) 
Indicates a use may be allowed in the respective district only where approved by the Bastrop Planning Commission in accordance with Sec. 16.2.9, Special Use Permit. Special use permits are subject to all other applicable requirements of this zoning development code, including all applicable use standards. 

D.	 Blank Cell 
A blank cell indicates that a use is not allowed in the respective district. 

E. Use Standard 
Indicates a cross-reference to any associated use standard established in Sec. 7.3, Residential Use Standards, through Sec. 7.7,Open Use Standards. Where no cross-reference is shown, no additional use standard applies.

3.4.8 Large Format Shopfront 


3.4.8 Large Format Shopfront 

A building type intended primarily for large format single-story retail. Storefront windows are provided to encourage interaction between the pedestrian and the

3.5.1 Suburban Planned Development (S-PD) 
Sec. 3.5 Special Development Standards 

3.5.1 Suburban Planned Development (S-PD) 
A.	 General Provisions 
1. 	The Bastrop City Council may approve a suburban planned development subject to the following standards and the process in 16.2.12, Proce­dures, Planned Development. The suburban planned development is intended to facilitate the use of innovative techniques of land develop­ment and site design concepts that achieve a high level of environmen­tal sensitivity, energy e.ciency, aesthetics, quality development and other community goals by: 
a. 	
Reducing or eliminating the in.exibility that may result from strict application of building type standards and permitted uses; and 

b. 	
Promoting quality urban design and environmentally sensitive development by allowing development to take advantage of special site characteristics, locations and land uses; and 

c. 	
Requiring compliance with development standards that re. ect the high level of public investment in adjoining lands. 


2. 	Each application for approval of a suburban planned development shall include a statement by the applicant describing: 
a. 	
How the proposed development departs from the otherwise appli­cable standards of this zoning development code; and 

b. 	
How the proposed development is an improvement over what would be required under otherwise applicable development regulations. 


B. Minimum Size 
No suburban planned development less than 4 acres in size is allowed. 
C. Maximum Allowed ResidenO al Density 
No suburban planned development may exceed a gross residential density of 40 dwelling units per acre. 
3-30 | City of Bastrop 
ARTICLE 3. SUBURBAN 

D.	 Allowed DeviaOons 
Unless otherwise expressly approved by the Bastrop City Council as part of the approved rezoning and concept plan, all suburban planned develop­ments shall be subject to all applicable standards of this zoning develop­ment code. In order to approve modi.cations of otherwise applicable standards, the Bastrop City Council must . nd that: 
1. 	
Requested deviations from applicable building type standards, allowed uses, or other development standards that otherwise would apply are justi.ed by the compensating bene.ts of the planned unit develop­ment; and 

2. 	
The suburban planned development includes adequate provisions for all necessary services including but not limited to utility service, waste water service, and emergency vehicle access.
